Caption and running title: The miseries of civil-war.
Based on the second part of Shakespeare's King Henry the Sixth.
First edition. Reissued in 1681 with new title: Henry the Sixth, the second part, or, The misery of civil war.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A TRAGEDY, As it is Acted at the DUKE's Theatre, By His Royal Highneſſes Servants.
LONDON, Printed for R. Bentley, and M. Magnes, in Ruſſel-Street in Covent-Garden, 1680.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: REligious Broyles to ſuch a height are grown,
All the ſweet ſound of Poetry they drown.
Were Orpheus here, his Lute might charm our Beaſts,
Our Maſtiffs, not our Robble, or our Prieſts.
Good Heaven! Sirs! are there no other ways
To damn the Pope, but damning all our Plays?
To our Religion 'tis no Praiſe at all,
That, if our Wit muſt ſtand, our Faith muſt fall.
All parties in a Play-Houſe may agree,
The Stage is priviledg'd from Piety.
'Tis pleaſant, Sirs, to ſee you fight and brawl
About Religion, but have none at all.
Moſt fiercely for the Road to Heav'n contend,
But never care to reach the Journeys end.
Though you loſe Heaven, you will keep the Way,
The Pope ſha'n't have you, though the Devil may.
Theſe things ſuch buſineſs for the Criticks find,
They're not at leaſure Poetry to mind,
Well for the Poet 'tis they're ſo employ'd;
Elſe this poor Work of his wou'd be deſtroy'd.
For by his feeble Skill 'tis built alone,
The Divine Shakeſpear did not lay one Stone.
Beſides this Tragedy a Rod will prove,
To whip us for a Fault, we too much Love,
And have for ages liv'd, call'd Civil Strife.
The Engliſh Nation, like a Ruſſian Wife,
Is to a gentle Husband always curſt,
And loves him beſt, who uſes her the worſt.
This Poet, (though perhaps in Colours faint)
Thoſe ſcurvy Joys does in all Poſtures Paint
Fools take in pelting out each others Brains:
A joy, for which this Nation oft takes pains.
If any like the Ills he ſhews to day,
Let them be damn'd and let them damn the Play.

div.head: The Perſons Repreſented in the Tragedy.

row.cell: KIng Henry the Sixth, Prince Edward, King Henry's Son.
Edward, eldeſt Son of Richard Plantagenet, and after his Fathers death King of England,
George, Duke of Clarence, ſecond Son of the Duke of York,
Richard, the third Son, called Crook-back,
Rutland a Child, the youngeſt Son.
Queen Margaret, Wife of King Henry,
Lady Grey, the Widow of Sir John Grey, belov'd and at length married by King Edward the fourth,
Lady Elianor Butler, a young Lady of great quality, that was one of King Edward's Miſtreſſes,

div.head: ACT. I. SCENE. I.
A Noiſe of Fighting; a Shout for Victory.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: FLing all my dead Subjects into the Thames.
Now ſay, what place is this?

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.l: 'Tis London-Stone.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Then am I Mortimer, Lord of this City;
And here, I, ſitting upon London-Stone,
Declare, this is the firſt day of our Reign.
So I command the Conduits all Piſs Claret:
And I proclaim it Treaſon now for any man
To call me other than Lord Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Jack Cade, Jack! Jack!

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Knock down that ſawcy Fellow.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.l: If he has wit, he'll never call thy Honour
Jack Cade again.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: I think he has fair warning.

div.stage: Enter a Cobler, with a Scrivener.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: My Lord! my Lord!

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Well ſaid, a mannerly Fellow.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: I have catch'd a Scrivener here, ſetting Boyes Copies.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Oh! there's a Villain! a corrupter of Youth.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: He has a Book in's pocket with red Letters in't.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Then he's a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: He can write Bills, and Bonds, and Obligations, to bind
People to undo themſelves, and pay Money, whether they
Can or no; ſuch a Rogue is enough to undo a Nation.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: I'm ſorry for it, for on my honour he's a proper fellow:
He ſhall not dye unleſs I find him Guilty.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: He ſhall die, Guilty or not Guilty; I brought him to be
Hang'd, and I will not loſe my labour. I love hanging, there's
Never any hanging, but I leave my Stall to go ſee it.
Hanging-day is my holy-day, and I will keep Coblers holy-day.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: We'll hang him, but we'll examine him firſt.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: No hang him firſt, for now no man will confeſs,
Till after he's hang'd.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: I will examine him.—Sirrah! what's thy Name!

sp.speaker: Scriv.
sp.l: Emanuel.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Emanuel!
That's a ſtrange Name, Friend 'twill go very hard with you.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Let me alone! Friend, doſt thou write thy Name,
Or uſe a mark like a plain honeſt man?

sp.speaker: Scriv.
sp.l: Sir. I thank Heaven, I have been ſo well bred,
That I can write my name.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: He has confeſt,
He's a ſtranger, and a Villain, hang him.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Hang him with his Pen and Ink about his Neck.

div.stage: Enter others with the Lord Say Priſoner.
div.l: My Lord, my Lord, a prize an't like thy Honour.
Here's the Lord Say, who ſold the Townes in France,
And made us pay one and twenty Fifteens
And a ſhilling to the pound, laſt Subſidy.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: I will behead him one and twenty times.
Come ſcurvy Lord, what canſt thou ſay
To our Mightineſs, for giving up our Towns
To Monſieur Baſimecu; the Dolphin of France?
Be it known unto thee, Traytor, by theſe preſents,
Even by the preſence of my ſelf, Lord Mortimer,
That I will ſweep the world clean of ſuch filth.
Thou Trayterouſly haſt built a Grammar-School,
To debauch all the youth, and whereas formerly
Our Grandſiers us'd no Book, but Score and Tally,
Thou haſt caus'd wicked Printing to be us'd,
And contrary to the King, his Crown and Dignity,
Haſt built a Paper-Mill. It will be prov'd,
That thou haſt Servants talk of Nouns and Verbs,
And ſuch vile Words no Chriſtian er'e can here.
Thou haſt appointed Juſtices of Peace,
To call poor men before 'em, about matters
They cou'd not anſwer; yes, and thou haſt hang'd 'em,
Becauſe they cou'd not read.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: There was a Villain!

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Thou rid'ſt upon a foot-cloth, doſt thou not?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Well what of that?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Why is it not a ſhame
Thy Horſe ſhou'd weare a Cloak, when honeſt men
Go in their Hoſe and Doublets?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Well, I find
You men of Kent—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: What of us men of Kent?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: That Kent is, bona terra mala gens.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Bold Traytor, he ſpeaks Latin in my preſence.
Go hang him, hang him.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Hear me, Country-men.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Hear Latin! Villain? hang him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hang him, hang him.—

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.l: We'll hang up every man that can ſpeak-Latin.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Well counſel'd Butcher, counſel'd like a Butcher.
We will, and more, for they are but few.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: We'll hang up any man that can ſpeak French.
For I'm a Taylour, and there is no man
That can ſpeak French will let me work a ſtitch for 'em.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: We'll hang up all the Lords and Gentlemen.
Spare none but ſuch as go in clouted ſhoes;
For I'm a Cobler, and live by thoſe.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.l: But by your favour, Sir, I am a Taylor
And, Sir, I live by Lords and Gentlemen;
I only wou'd hang thoſe that owe me money,
And will not pay me.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Why, thou ſtiching Coxcomb!
We will be Lords and Gentlemen our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.l: Oh! that's another thing.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Another thing!
What do we fight for elſe, you ſilly Raſcal?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: 'Tis true, my Lord, we ought to be Great-men,
For it is ſaid, Labour in thy Vocation:
That is, let Magiſtrates be labouring-men,
Therefore we lab'ring men ought to be Magiſtrates;
And I will be Lord Cobler, and a Counſellor.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.l: I'le be Lord Carpenter, for 'tis a ſhame
That none of the Kings Council are good Workmen.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: The Lords, forſooth ſcorn to wear leather Aprons.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: We'll make 'em glad to go in leather Aprons.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.l: We'll ſtick 'em all, and we'll be Lords our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.l: I'll be contented to be but a Knight.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Shall we not ſpare the Lords that are our friends,
Such as thy Couſin Plantagenet, and others?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: No Lord is our Friend, you Fool, they meerly chouſe us.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.l: How / meerly chouſe us?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: I ſay meerly chouſe us.
All the fine words and money that they give us
Is nothing elſe but buying of Calves-heads.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.l: My Cleaver then ſhall chouſe 'em of their Brains.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: When they have done with us, they'l turn us off.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.l: Here are brave Knaves.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.l: His Honour underſtands 'em.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: I Gad, my Lord's a deviliſh parlous Fellow.
Prethee, my Lord, what ail's theſe plaguy Lords
To keep this coyl, when they have a power o' money,
Brave Lands, and gallant Wenches to their Wives?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: I'll tell thee Tom the Cobler, here's my ſhoe;
Doſt thou believe my ſhoe, if it had wit,
Wou'd carry me up and down all day i'th dirt;
Or doſt thou think my Breeches wou'd be ſat on,
Or Doublet cloath my Back, and by that means
Be often cudgell'd, if they had any wit;
No, if they had any wit, they would be Caps.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: True, but thy worſhip's Cap is ſometimes cudgell'd:
I have known thy Honour have a broken pate.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Ay but pride feels no hurt; ſo ſome great Lords
Are trodden under foot like dirty ſhoes,
Some hang like Doublets on the Nations back,
And ſome like Breeches only on the tayl.
But by their good wills they would all be Caps,
And ſo wou'd you my friends if you be wiſe.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: We'll all be Caps.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: All Caps, all Caps, all Caps.

sp.speaker: Cade
sp.l: If you'll be Caps, hang all Lords and Gentlemen,
And all rich Citizens.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.l: How, all rich Citizens?
Prithee my Lord, they are my particular Friends,
They buy more Meat, than all the Lords in England.
And then they promiſe they'll do great things for us,
If we will help 'em to redreſs their Grievances.

sp.speaker: Cad.
sp.l: Butcher, thoſe promiſes are but a meer cheat,
Theſe men puff thee, juſt as thou blowſt thy Veal,
Only to make thee ſwell for their own ends.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.l: Are they ſuch Knaves?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Oh they are notorious Knaves,
They cheat the Town, their Wives, themſelves, and us.
They ſit up nightly a Plotting, and Caballing,
So cheat their Wives of due benevolence,
They leave their Shops a-days, for State-Affairs,
So cheat themſelves of money they might get,
And cheat the Town of Trade that it might have,
And laſt they mean to cheat us of our Necks,
Put us on Plots for them, then have us hang'd.
Now my good ſubjects we are bound in Conſcience,
To take their Wives and give 'em due Benevolence,
To take their Shops, and give the Town it's due,
To hang the men, and give the Rope it's due,
And ſo we ſhall be very honeſt fellows.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ay, Ay, we ſhall be very honeſt fellows.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: In ſhort we'll ha' no Trades but Eating, and
Drinking. We'll have ſeven half-penny Loaves
For a Farthing, and a Pint-pot ſhall hold a
Gallon; and ſo let us about our hanging work.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Go, Subjects, go, but pray remember one thing,
To hang the Lawyers when your hand is in.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: I warrant thee, my Lord, we'll hang the Lawyers:
But now I think on't they wear out
Abundance of Shoo-leather in going to Weſt-Minſter.
Hall, and employ Coblers much.
Beſides they help to undo Lords, and Gentlemen.
But now I think on't we can undo 'em
Faſt enough our ſelves, by burning their Houſes,
And taking their Lands. The Lawyers
Have a ſure way of undoing 'em, but it's more tedious,
Ours is moſt quick, and as ſure;
So we ſhall have no uſe o' the Lawyers,
And ſo lets hang 'em.
And for that reaſon too
Let's hang the Doctors and Pothecaries.
For though they do kill Gentry pretty well,
Yet we have a better, quicker way;
By knocking 'em o' the head.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Subjects, hang the Doctors and Pothecaries, but
Hang the Lawyers firſt, for fear they
Hang you—for when you have had
A thouſand broken heads, and ſettled all things,
As right as you wou'd wiſh, a Roguy Lawyer
Will ruine all again with a meer quirk.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: A quirk! what's a quirk?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: —A quirk—why 'tis a quirk—

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Well, but what is a quirk?

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.l: What's matter what a quirk is? I know
What my Lord means by quirk.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Do you ſo, Sir: Then you are a Scholar are
You? Sir, as little learning as this has made
Many a man a Prieſt, you deſerve to have
Your brains beaten out.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.l: My brains?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Hold Cobler and Butcher! Civil VVars
Among our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: I hate Scholars, I will have no man live
Among us that knows more than I.
But I wou'd know what a quirk is.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Doſt know what an Awl is?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: I think I do.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Then as thou boreſt holes in ſhoes with
Thy Awl to mend 'em, Lawyers with quirks bore
Holes in Eſtates to mar 'em.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: For this, and other reaſons hang the Lawyers.
They ſtrive to make the Subjects break the Law,
And then they make the Law break all the Subjects,
And cunningly they make ſuch rotten Laws,
That men muſt break 'em all ſpite of their Teeth,
We ſend (you know) ſometimes men to make Laws,
And there theſe men ſit hatching Laws and Laws,
And as they think hatch ſound and wholeſome Laws:
A plaguy Lawyer gets his finger in,
And put's ſuch ſcurvy quirks into the Law,
That when 'tis hatch'd, I Gad the rotten Law
Fall's all to pieces like a pocky Child.

sp.speaker: Butch.
sp.l: There are pure Knaves for you, ſince they
Are for quirks,
We'll go and put ſuch quirks in the Inns of Court
Shall tumble them all down about their ears.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Do, honeſt ſubjects, do.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: We will, my Lord.
And prithee let thy mouth be all the Law.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Cobler well ſaid, my mouth ſhall be the Law,
For all the Law of England is but mouth;
When you are at law, it is not the beſt cauſe,
But the beſt mouth that always carries it.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Prithee let thy month be Weſtminſter-Hall,
And my mouth ſhall be Paul's:
For we ha' no uſe o' Churches, nor Steeples,
Nor Prieſts, the chief uſe o' Prieſts is to eat
Pig, we can eat Pig as well as they.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: We have no uſe o' the Inns of Court, or Tower,
Pluck down the Tower, and burn all the Records,
Why ſhou'd we keep
Mouldy Records of what our Grandſiers did?
For we do what we will for all our Grandſiers
On London bridge hang Traytours heads, and quarters.
Theſe are Records too, but who minds Records?
Burn all Records—Records?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Burn all Records.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Who ſounds a parley there?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: One from the King.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Well let him come, I don't care if I ſpeak with him.
Well what's thy buſineſs with me?

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: Thou vile Rebel,
VVhy doſt thou thus diſturb the King, and Kingdome?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Thou Fool, to have my own, I'm heir to the Crown.

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: Impudent Slave, thy Father was a Plaiſterer.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Yes, and his Mother was a Midwife, what's that?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: VVell, Adam was a Gardiner, what's that?
Say, did not Edmund Mortimer, Earl of March
Marry the Daughter o' the Duke of Clarence?

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: He did, Sir Clown, and what is that to you?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: By her he had two Children at a Birth;
The Elder of 'em being put to Nurſe,
Was ſtole away by a ſtinking Beggar-woman,
(Like a damn'd curſed jade) and by that means
The Princely Infant was bred up a Brick-layer,
And I'm the Princely Off-ſpring of that Infant.

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: Plantagenet invented this fine ſtory.

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: You lye, for I invented it my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: I am ſent by the King to offer pardon
To all that will forſake thee, and go home.
VVhat ſay you Countrymen, will you be happy
And leave this Rogue, or follow him and be hang'd?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I don't know what to think on't?

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Are you muttering?
VVhy, you damn'd fools, will you believe a Lord?
Do they not often run into your Debts,
And promiſe payment, and ne're keep their words?
Do they not often with fine promiſes
Delude your Daughters, and when they have enjoyed them,
Do they e're keep their words? Then follow me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A Cade, a Cade! we'll follow thee, Jack Cade.

sp.speaker: Old. Cl.
sp.l: You'll follow Cade? pray whither, to the Gallows?
He has no other home to lead you to.
He knows not how to live but by the ſpoil;
But ſay that whilſt you robb and kill your Country-men,
The fearful French whom you but lately vanquiſht,
Shou'd make a ſtart o're Seas and vanquiſh you;
Had you not better go and ſpoil the French,
And the King pay you too for your good ſervice,
Than here Rebel, and the King hang you all
For Rogues, or worſe, the French come make you ſlaves?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I don't know what to think on't—

sp.speaker: Cade.
sp.l: Again muttering?
VVho'll ever truſt ſuch curſed whiſling Raſcals?

sp.speaker: Yo. Cl.
sp.l: What are you doing, my Lord? treating with Raſcals?
It were too vile an Office for a Scavenger,
To ſweep ſuch dirt into the Common ſhore?
And are you treating with 'em? Nay, and treating
In the Kings name too? very fine indeed,
The King muſt barter for his Crown with Raſcals,
What ever price the Villains make him pay,
Though his Crown ſhou'd be dear, himſelf is cheap,
I with no Tongue but this will talk to Rebels.

div.stage: [Draws, all fight on the Stage. Ex.
The Scene a Tent. Enter King Henry.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Never had King leſs joy in Throne than I,
Nor more misfortune. Heaven was pleas'd to ſet
My Cradle on the top of humane Glory,
Where I lay helpleſs, open to all Storms.
My Childiſh hand, not able to ſupport
My Fathers Sword, dropt the victorious point,
And let fall all the Lawrels that adorn'd it,
And French and Engliſh fell a ſcrambling for 'em,
So loſt I France; now am I threatned too
By wicked Rebels, with the loſs of England.
Cade and his Rebels drive me from my City,
Plantagenet ſeek's to drive me from my Kingdom.

div.stage: Enter the Queen, and her Train.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Take comfort, Sir, I bring you happy tidings.
The Villain Cade is kill'd by brave young Clifford.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Kill'd!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Kill'd, and all the Rebels beg your mercy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Oh! Heav'n accept my vows of thanks and praiſe.
But ha! here comes his gallant Father weeping.

sp.speaker: Ol. Cl.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I weep, but I weep tears of Joy,
For I am cruſh'd between two mighty Joyes;
Your Royal ſafety, and my Sons ſucceſs.
But here he is, to tell you his own ſtory.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cl.
sp.l: Sir, I moſt humbly here preſent your Majeſty
The Head of the notorious Rebel Cade.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Oh! Gallant Clifford, how ſhall I reward thee?

sp.speaker: Yo. Cl.
sp.l: I fought not for rewards, or if I did,
I ought to end my work, e're I be paid,
I have only now pull'd down a paltry Scaffold,
On which Plantagenet deſign'd to climbe,
To build his Trayt'rous Projects.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: True indeed,
He is approaching me with a great Army;
But he gives out he only does intend
To drive away from me ſome wicked Miniſters.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cl.
sp.l: The conſtant vizard of Rebellion.
Rebellion is ſo foul and grim a Monſter,
That thoſe that mount the horrid Beaſt, are forc'd
To cover it all o're with gaudy Trappings.
They mark it in the Forehead with white ſtarrs,
Pretences Heavenly, and Innocent.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Sir, he has told you a moſt excellent truth.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs I like not to have Subjects
Preſent their Kings Petitions upon Pikes.

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: Sir, let the Rebels come, we are prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: A Trumpet from Plantagenet craves audience.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Admit him.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: Royal Sir, the Duke my maſter
Does beg admiſſion to your Kingly preſence,
To give you the true Reaſon of his arming,
And prove his Loyalty.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Juſt as we thought.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Go tell my Couſin, ſince he ſpeaks ſo fair,
He ſhall have free acceſs and all kind uſage.

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: What do you mean Sir?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: To throw far from my ſelf
The guilt of all the ill that may enſue.
He ſhall not ſay that I refus'd to hear,
Or to redreſs any juſt grievances.

sp.speaker: Y. Cl.
sp.l: Sir, you will find your ſelf will be the grievance.
The Tricks of theſe ambitious men are, firſt
To poiſon all the People with diſloyalty,
And when they have made 'em ſick, they tell 'em nothing
Can cure 'em but fome flowers out of the Crown;
And ſo they ſet the rabble raving for 'em.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Lord Clifford when the haughty rebelcom e's
Arreſt him of High-Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: I will do it, Madam.

div.stage: Enter Plantagenet, Edward, Richard, George: Plant. kneels, and kiſſes the Kings Hand.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Welcome dear Couſin. Pray acquaint me faithfully,
What do you mean by all the Troops you bring?

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Only to drive ſome Traytours from your preſence.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I know no greater Traytors than your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: And therefore I arreſt thee of High-Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Arreſt me! ha! Shall it be thus King Henry?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: It ſhall not be, I promis'd him ſafe Conduct.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: My Lord, we'll be your Bail.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: See, I have Bail.
Lord Clifford, in whoſe name do you Arreſt me?

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: In the Kings Name.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Then I'll unfold my ſelf.
Know hitherto I've been like a dark Cloud,
Where ſcorching heat has been ingendring Thunder:
The grumbling and the rowling you have heard,
But now the deadly bolt ſhall light among you▪
I am your King.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Yes, I am Your King.
I'm ſprung out of the Royal houſe of Clarence,
Whom three uſurpers of the houſe of Lancaſter
Succeſſively have trodden under feet,
Whilſt they have glittered in our Royal Glory,
Shone like falſe Diamonds in our royal Robes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Now, Sir, are we convinc'd we told you truth.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: And my next Title is the only Claim;
Duke Henry, (for I'll call him now no otherwiſe)
Duke Henry borrows from his bloody Grand Father
Henry the Fourth, I've twenty thouſand men,
But with this difference, Henry's Troops were Villains
Depoſers of their lawful Sov'reign Richard,
Mine are defenders of their true King Richard,
I mean my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Was ever ſuch Ambitious
Frenzy as this?

sp.speaker: Y. Cl.
sp.l: Did not we tell you this?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: And we will tell you more, obey your King
I mean my Royal Father, or our Swords
Shall turn the Arreſt of Treaſon on your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: Surely you think you are among your Beauties,
Amorous Edward, there your Vigour lies.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Let them admire thy boaſts, here thou art ſcorn'd.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: 'Tis ſaid when the brave Duke of Suffolk liv'd,
Queen Margaret would not contemn a Lover.
I'm young, and love, but yet I am not ſtricken
So blind with beauty, but I can diſcern
Both the fair Kingdom, and the fair Queen lye
Sick of the impotence of a Weak King.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ill manner'd inſolence!

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why do you talk
To this poor wretched Neapolitan?
She and her Husband are fit for each other;
He has no heart, and ſhe no heart for him.
Fortune loathed him as ſoon as e're ſhe ſaw him,
Nor from his Cradle never wou'd endure him,
And her ſhe never did think worth her care.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Why! well ſaid ugly Crook-back! ſpoken like
Thy hideous horrid ſelf:
I will not do thee ſo much good to kill thee.
Thy Soul cannot be worſe than where it is.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: He bears about him what is more deform'd
Than humane ſhape can be, his wickedneſs.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: I've ſhewed my right, and here are my three Sons
To plead it with their Swords, now I'll produce
My laſt and ſtrongeſt Title to the Crown,
The ſword of the victorious Earl of Warwick.
Call in the Earl of Warwick.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I am here

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Inform the ignorant world who is King of England,

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Whom my ſword pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Thou againſt me Warwick!
What did'ſt thou never ſwear Allegiance to me?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: 'Cauſe I adored an idol once in ignorance,
Muſt I ſtill do ſo, now I ſee my error?
Know Duke of Lancaſter (for you are no more)
Henry your Grand Father murdered his King
Richard the ſecond, not content with that,
He trampled on the rights of the next heirs.
Your Father warlick Henry, I confeſs,
Had in deſert what he did want in Title.
But merit makes no lawful claim to Crowns,
For if it did, I wou'd be King of England.
But I will tell you to your face, Duke Henry;
That you have neither Title nor Deſert:

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Moſt impudent of Traytours.

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: Moſt impudent of Traytours.

sp.speaker: Y. Cl.
sp.l: Moſt impudent of Traytours.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I'll ſpeak truth,
And value not the fury of you all.
Your Father Henry was a Wall of ſteel
Through which there was no paſſing to the throne,
But you are only a ſoft ſilken Curtain,
Which with my hand or breath I'll put aſide,
And ſeat your ſelf King Richard in the Throne,
For it is empty though the Duke be there,
The Duke is nothing, or ſuch poor thin ſoft ſtuff
The Crown ſinks down in him, and is not ſeen.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cl.
sp.l: What, have theſe Traytours conquer'd us already.
They talk at this bold rare? Thou Traytour Warwick!—
Warwick? no!—when thou didſt unking thy King
Thou mad'ſt thy ſelf a Groom; by the ſame law,
Thou trampleſt on thy King, a ſawcy Groom
May ſet his dirty foot upon thy jaws,
And tell thee they were made both of one Clay.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: The duke of Lancaſter's no King of mine.

sp.speaker: Y. Cl.
sp.l: VVhence haſt thou this? from Lawyers, and from Scriblers?
Say, the King's Grand-father Murther'd his King
And damn'd his Soul for it, what's that to thee?
Say, our proſterity ſhou'd wrong each other,
VVhat muſt their Servants cudgel 'em to honeſty?
Oh! But old ſtories cenſure the King's Title;
Are royal Robes made of ſuch raggs as Pamphlets?
Yes, when a beggar feign wou'd put 'em on,
One that wou'd beg the Kingdom from the people,
And ſuch a beggar is Plantagenet.
Oh! but the lawyers like not the Kings Title:
VVhat ſhall the lawyers be the Kingdoms Oracles,
And judge their Kings, who ſpeak but as inſpir'd
By the Kings Image ſtampt upon his Gold?
Let the King give 'em ſtore of golden Pictures
And they will give him a ſubſtantial title.
And then the Noble-men muſt be the Bayliffs
To execute the ſentence of the Coyfe.
Damn thy pedantick Treaſon; thou art as far
From wit as honour, and that's far enough.
VVho ſtopps a River's head up, drie's the ſtream;
Thou haſt divided thy ſelf from thy King,
The ſpring of honour, ſo thou haſt no honour.
But art a heap of dirty peſantry,
Fit only to manure a brave mans fortune;
A ſtraying Beaſt, with the Devil's mark upon thee,
Rebellion, and I'll ſend thee to thy owner.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: What a fierce talker's this?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I laugh at him;
All this loud noiſe and fury you have heard,
Is but the crackling of ſome burning thorns,
That hedge the Duke, and they will ſoon be aſhes.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: No more Duke Henry, will you yield my Crown,
Or ſhall we fall upon you?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Muſt it be ſo?
Let us not bloodily Butcher one another;
But fairly to the field, and there in Battle
Make an Appeal to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Y. Cl.
sp.l: Then royal Henry, fixt on loyal Clifford,
Stand like a Cedar on a Mountain top
Securely rooted, and deſpiſe all ſtorms.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: My cauſe is ſixt on Heav'n, for it is juſt.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then ſound to Armes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: To Armes, to Armes, to Armes.—

div.head: ACT. II.
div.stage: Enter Warwick and Souldiers chaſing others over the Stage. Enter Plantagent, and Old Clifford fighting.—Old Clifford falls.

sp.speaker: P
sp.l: FArewell, old valiant Clifford, I ſhou'd now
Be ſorry for thee, wer't thou not my Enemy.

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: Be ſorry for thy ſelf, thou art a Traytour,
And I for loyalty die honourably.

sp.speaker: Y. Cl.
sp.l: Shame and Confuſion, all is on the rout.
My men are fled or kill'd, and I alone
Stand like a lofty Maſt, ſhewing my head
Above the Waves, when all the Ship is ſunk,
I cannot find my Father not my King.

sp.speaker: Old. Cl.
sp.l: Son!

sp.speaker: Yo. Cl.
sp.l: I heard a voice reſembling much
My Fathers, very weak and faint it ſeemed,
As he were far from me, or near to death.

sp.speaker: Old Cl.
sp.l: Son!

sp.speaker: Yo. Cl.
sp.l: Ha! again he calls! Oh! there he lyes!
All weltring in his gore, gaſping for life.
Oh! Father! Father! if thou haſt breath enough,
Leave with me but the name of him that wounded thee
That I may give thee and my ſelf revenge,
And I'll prefer that glorious Legacy,
Before the Eſtate and Honour which thou leav'ſt me

sp.speaker: Ol. Cl.
sp.l: Plantagenet gave me my death!—Farewel—

sp.speaker: Y. Cl.
sp.l: Plantagenet gave thee thy death—Plantagenet
Then gave himſelf and all his race deſtruction.
He kills our old men, and I'll kill his Children.
Henceforth I will not have to do with pitty,
Tears ſhall be to me as the dew to fire,
I will be famous for inhumane cruelty,
My Father hear's me not, he's dead! he's gone.
Come thou new ruin of Old Clifford's houſe,
I'll bear thee on my ſhouldiers as Aeneas
Did old Anchiſes, but with this ſad difference,
He bore a living Father, mine is dead,
And ſo my burden and my grief is heavier.

div.stage: He takes his Father on his back, and going out meets the King, Queen, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Away, away, Sir, what do you mean to ſtay?
All's loſt, you have no ſafety but in flight.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: My heart's ſo heavy that I cannot flye.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Ha! who goes there? Clifford thou art, I think.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cl.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What burden haſt thou on thy ſhoulders.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cl.
sp.l: I carry vengeance for Plantagenet.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Plantagenet dead?

sp.speaker: Yo. Cl.
sp.l: A braver honeſter man,
My valiant loyal Father.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Clifford dead?

sp.speaker: Yo. Cl.
sp.l: Kill'd by Plantagenet.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Take comfort, Clifford.
We'll ſtreight to London, where we have pow'r enough
To revenge our ſelves and thee, and to aſſiſt us.
The Parliament ſhall meet and raiſe the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Yo. Cl.
sp.l: For your revenge ralſe Kingdoms and for mine,
I'll raiſe my ſelf, and I'll have bloody Vegeance,
I'll kill Plantagenet, and all his Sons
That when he is dead he may not have a Son.
To bear him to the grave, as I my Father;
And ſo cut off his memory from the Earth,
Meet I but any Infants of his Houſe,
Into as many gobbits will I cut 'em
As wild Medea did the young Abſyrtis,
And I will ſtrave my men that they may eat 'em,
And ſo let us about our ſeveral buſineſs.

div.stage: A Shout of Victory, Enter at one door Warwick, at another Plantagenet, Edward, Richard, Souldiers. Plantagenet embraces VVarwick.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Let me embrace the greateſt man that breaths.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Pray ceaſe, my Lord, you know this does not pleaſe me.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: England will learn again to Fight and Conquer,
A glorious ſcience we have almoſt loſt,
Under the reign of this tame bookiſh Henry.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What is become of the young boaſting Clifford?
Fate as if tender of him, did to day,
VVhen e're I met him, thruſt a crowd betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: I met his Father in the field; and there
I put the brave old man to his laſt bed.
The ſtout old winter Lyon, that had long
Endur'd the bruſh of time, fought with that heat,
As he had been but in the ſpring of youth.
Like arras-hangings in a homely houſe,
So was his gallant Spirit in his body

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Whilſt we purſued the hor •• men o' the North,
With too much heat, the King eſcap'd our hands;
But he has left behind ſome of his friends,
I fell upon the gallant Duke of Buckingham,
And with one fortunate ſubſtantial blow,
I cleft his good ſteel Helmet, and his Scull,
And ſee, his Brains are yet upon my Sword.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: To ſpeak the truth, my Brother Edward fought
To day, as if he had fought for a Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs, I fought with more diſpatch;
'Cauſe had the Battle laſted, 'twou'd have ſpoil'd
An aſſignation that I have to night.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Did not I ſay as much?

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Thou, good Son Richard,
Doſt not diſturb thy heart with cares of love.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: The hill upon my back fence's my heart;
The women love not me, ſo I hate them.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: We have all cut our names deep on the Pillars
Of Fame's high Temple, where ſhall be forever
Written this glorious Battle at S. Albons.
Now, my Lord, poſt away with ſpeed to London,
For thither I am told the King is Fled,
And there he will repair this day's wide breaches
Citizens always love Tame Godly Princes,
And ſuch as abhor fighting like themſelves.
Then, if you can, enter the Town before 'em,
And fill it with your Troops; and then tomorrow
Get very early into the Parliament Houſe,
And guarded well, openly claim the Crown.
My Tongue and Sword ſhall both aſſert your Title.
Then let me ſee, what Peer dare be ſo bold,
Or Common ſo ſawcy, to oppoſe it.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Thou Soul of valour, Wiſdom, and Nobility,
I'll take thy Counſel.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Go then march with ſpeed,
I'll tarry for a moment to take care
For any of quality that are dead or wounded.

div.stage: [Ex. Plantagenet, Richard one way, Warwick another.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I well approve this ſpeedy March to London,
For here to Night I hope to meet my Miſtreſs.

div.stage: Enter two bearing a Body, Warwick meets 'em.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Whoſe Body is that?
'Tis Sir John Grey of Grooby.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: A fierce bigot for the Lancaſtrian Faction.
I've heard of him, and whither do you carry him?
To his fair Widow; ſhe had only news
He had ſome wounds, and ſo came in her Chariot
To carry him away with her, but all
Her care is now too late; ſee here ſhe is.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Where is my Husband? I am impatient for him.
1. We have found him, Madam, in a ſtate too bad
For you to look on.

sp.speaker: L. Gr.
sp.l: Oh! he's dead! he's dead!
2. Help! help! ſhe's falling on him dead as he.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I never ſaw ſo beautiful a Creature.
1. She is come to her ſelf,

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: But I'm ſo loſt,
That I ſhall never be my ſelf again.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Oh! my dear Husband!

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: See! ſee! ſhe embalmes
His Body with her pretious Tears and Kiſſes.
I know not to what place his Soul is fled;
But I am ſure his Body is in Heaven.
Forms, Ceremonies, Civil Fooleries,
Inſects engendred of corrupt falſe Wit.
I will ride o're you in my way to joy;
Though this is the firſt time I ever ſaw her,
And ſhe lies drown'd in Tears o're her dead Husband
Drown'd in his blood, ſhed may be by my ſelf;
Yet here, and now I'll tell her that I Love;
And here, and now reſolve to make her mine.
Madam, your pardon that I interrupt you.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: You, Madam, beſt can tell,
When I came hither I was Earl of Warwick;
But you have chang'd me to I know not what.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: The Earl of Warwick! Oh! my Lord I beg you,
Conjure you by the Honour of a Nobleman,
That you permit a miſerable Woman
To give her Husbands Body decent Burial.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Madam, with all my heart; and I cou'd wiſh
He had been buried when he firſt ſaw light,
And never liv'd to do Prodigious miſchiefs.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: What wondrous miſchiefs dying for his King?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Oh! he has done more ill, than Frantick Alexander
When he ſet fair Perſepolis o' Fire,
Or him that burnt the fam'd Epheſian Temple.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Who did all this?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: He, whom Heav'n there has puniſht;
And did it, Madam, by enjoying you,
By kindling in your heart love for himſelf,
He fir'd a ſtately Palace, only fit
For hearts of mighty Kings, He burnt a Temple
The maſter piece of Nature, the Worlds wonder.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Is this fit talk to one in my condition?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I know old Tyrant Cuſtom does command
You Widows to be ſtretch'd on the long rack
Of twelve months mournful abſtinence from love.
And, which methinks is an immodeſt faſhion,
You muſt wear black the colour of the night,
To put you in remembrance of the pleaſure.
Night for your ſervice pays you no more Wages,
Yet you in gratitude muſt wear Nights livery.
And you muſt ſigh aud weep to tell the World
What skill you have in man, for who e're weeps
For loſs of that whoſe value they ne're knew?
Fy! what ill woman brought up thoſe ill Cuſtoms?

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: What horrid inſolence you treat me with?
My Lord, the Enemy begins to rally.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Go fight 'em, for I'm buſily employ'd.
Mount, mount, my Lord, or you'l be taken Priſoner.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I am a Priſoner, nor can ſtir from hence;
Unleſs this beauty with a ſmile releaſe me.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Grief, Horror, and Confuſion put me again
Into a deadly Fainting.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I perceive
Formality the Governeſs of Women,
And Cuſtom the great Tyrant of the World
Are married in the Temple of this beauty.
Take with you then your pale Companion,
And pay to it the Tax of ſome Months tears,
And lock your ſelf in ſolitude and darkneſs,
But after that by my renown and fortune,
By this days victory, by that great power,
By which I to the King ſay, be a Subject;
And to a Subject I ſay, be a King.
I ſwear I ſhortly will ſay to my ſelf,
Warwick, be thou Poſſeſſour of this beauty.
I'll have you, though you hate, and Heaven envy me,
And the firſt joy I reap coſt me my life.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: In ſpight of me I am compel'd to ſpeak,
I ſwear by the dead body of my Husband,
By my unſpotted fame moſt ſacred to me,
I rather will chuſe death than any man,
But I'll chuſe Hell e're you.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Cruelly ſworn;
But yet ſuch Oaths are heriots, which Widows
To cuſtom always pay, when a life falls.
The world expects to have 'em pay ſuch ſines,
E're they renew another life in love.
Then, Madam, take your fallen tenement,
And pay all cuſtom'd dues, you have your freedom.
And for your ſafety all my guard ſhall wait you.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Though paying rights of burial to my husband
Be all that I deſire to do on Earth,
E're I will be oblig'd to you for any thing,
I'll dye upon him and be all his monument.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Oh Beauteous Monument! all men wou'd dye
To be ſo buried!—envy will not ſuffer me
To let the dead have ſo much happineſs,
Therefore I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: The only favour
I will receive, or can endure from you.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Take it, one kindneſs oft begets another,
Farewel, moſt cruel, but moſt beauteous creature.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Farewel moſt rude and moſt abhorr'd of men.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Guard her ſafe hence, but do not let her know it,
Leſt ſhe refuſe it, and ſhou'd meet with injury.

div.stage: Scene a Room in London, Table, Lights.
Enter Edward pulling in Lady Elianor Butler.

sp.speaker: L. El.
sp.l: Oh! do not tempt me, for I know
You will be falſe.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Well but I know I ſhall not.

sp.speaker: L. El.
sp.l: Oh! to how many women have you ſworn
As much as you ha' done to me to night?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh is there not great difference among VVomen?
Some Women are but petty Inns to lodg at,
And though perhaps rather than want a lodging,
We wou'd pay all they ask, though moſt unreaſonable:
But if they wou'd pay me, I wou'd not dwell with 'em;
But your ſweet beauty is my journey's end.

sp.speaker: L. El.
sp.l: Oh! yes till you begin another journey.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Beſides the many thouſand Charmes about you,
From which it is impoſſible to 'ſcape,
Your Birth and Quality will not permit me
To trifle with you as with trifling women,
I dare not but regard Lady Elianor Butler.

sp.speaker: L. El.
sp.l: But when you have enjoy'd Lady Elianour Butler,
She'l ſeem as very a trifle as the reſt.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Then what a perjur'd Villain muſt I be?

sp.speaker: L. El.
sp.l: VVhen you are Prince of Wales, perhaps you'l think
The Prince of Wales is not obliged to keep
Lord Edwards Oaths, and when I follow you,
You will cry, Madam, I am Prince of Wales,
And I muſt marry for the Nation's good;
I'm very ſorry I am forc'd to loſe you,
But pardon me, it is the Nation's fault.
So, Madam, I'm your very humble Servant,
If I can ſerve you any way, command you;
Then inſtead of being made Princeſſe of Wales
I ſneak away poor cheated Elianor Butler.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Well this is very unkind to make me throw
So ſweet a Night ſo fooliſhly away.
I thought you wou'd have given me a clear draught
Of Love without the dreggs of Oaths and Vows.

sp.speaker: L. El.
sp.l: Oh! you are too charming not to be belov'd,
And when once lov'd, not to be lov'd for ever.
I know I've not deſert to keep you conſtant;
And 'tis enough for me that you once lov'd me,
To blame you that you will not love me always,
• as a beggar blam'd a Prince, for giving him
Only one Jewel. No one Woman merit's
Your Love, ſo you divide it among all.
But oh! methinks I feign wou'd have it alle
And have it always.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: So I ſwear you ſhall.
Then come away, for night is ſtealing from us,
Weary with holding up her fable Robe,
To hide two loytring lovers to no purpoſe.
Then come away.

sp.speaker: L. El.
sp.l: Oh ſwear to me once more.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I'll ſwear no more, whil'ſt we by fooliſh Oaths
Secure delights to come, we loſe the preſent.
Then come away, for elſe I ſhall be call'd.
Oh Heaven's! ſee! the day is broke already.
The vaſt and heavy buſineſs of a Kingdom
Heave up the ſcale of Morn before it's time.
Oh! come away for fear I be undone.

sp.speaker: L. El.
sp.l: Oh! do not ask for fear I be undone.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Hark! I hear knocking! I am call'd, I'm ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: My Lord! here is your Brother my Lord Richard
Is come to fetch you to the Parliament,
He ſays, your Father's going thither already.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Did not I tell you, Love, what you wou'd do?
Confound my Lord Richard, tell him I'm not here.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: He ſays you are here, and he'l not part with you.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: So, we have manag'd our occaſion finely.
Was this well done of you?

sp.speaker: L. El.
sp.l: You may forgive me,
Since I'm almoſt as ſorry as you are.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Then will you mend the fault another time?

sp.speaker: L. El.
sp.l: I fancy I ſhall do my weak endeavour.

sp.speaker: Rich. within.
sp.l: Why, Brother!—

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Heark he calls! I muſt be gone,
Farewel, my dear, remember what you have promis'd.

sp.speaker: L. El.
sp.l: Remember you your Vows of conſtancy.

sp.speaker: Rich. within.
sp.l: Brother, what do you mean? leave your damn'd Women,
For I'm ſure 'tis ſome damn'd Woman ſtays you.
But for my part I'll ſtay no longer for you.
For I will not be chidden for your faults,
My Father, and his Friends ſhall know how it is.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Thank thee, good natur'd honeſt vertuous Brother;
How proud this Leper is of one ſound place?
Though he has all the vices in the world,
Yet he inſults o're me, becauſe he is free
From my one fault, my almoſt faultleſs fault.
He is a Hell at whoſe foul front appears,
Ill manners, and ill nature, and ill ſhape,
Like a three-headed Dog, that barks at all things
That dare come near him, ſpecially at beauty;
But has within a thouſand ugly Haggs
His Soul embraces, bloody cruelty,
Lean envy, and inſatiable Ambition.
And he has this advantage over me,
His Miſtreſſes are Devils, and ſo inviſible.
Some time or other I'll deſcend like Hercules
Into this Hell, and dragg to humane ſight
The Monſter that ſo barks at my delight.

div.stage: Scene the Parliament Houſe, a Throne, Canopy, Seats for the Lords.
Enter Plantagenet, George, Richard, Warwick, Clarence, Rutland, Guard all with drawn Swords.

sp.speaker: War,
sp.l: This is the palace of the fearful King,
And this the Regal Seat; Richard Plantagenet,
Sit down, and from this hour be King of England.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: I think if mighty Warwick ſaid, be Emperour
Of the whole world, the Genii of all Kingdoms
Wou'd vaniſh and give place to his great ſpirit.
Aſſiſted then by thee, I here ſit down,
And take poſſeſſion of my Royal Right.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I plant you here, now Root you up who dares.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Where's my Son Edward? Son? why loiter you?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Sir, why do you neglect your Father thus?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Reprov'd by Warwick? what does Warwick cheat us?
Give us a Crown to cheat us of our liberty?
Hire us to be his ſlaves? ſo ſoon ſo arrogant?
This humour I muſt quell, I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Sons, I here take poſſeſſion of my right,
And will be Crown'd or kill'd:—if I ſhou'd fall,
Son Edward, claim the Crown, if you fall with me,
Then, George, the Crown is thine, if both you dye,
Then, Richard, thou art King.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Three goodly Pillars,

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: And laſt in birth but not in my Affection.
Here is my litle pretty darling Rutland,
Look to him, Guard, for if his brothers Periſh,
He is your King; fear not my pretty Boy.
We'll be too hard for wretched timerous Henry.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Sir, let him come, and all his Souldiers with him.
If you will beat his Souldiers, I'll beat him.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Well ſaid my boy; and heark; I think he comes.

div.stage: Enter King Henry in his Robes, his Crown on his head, the Sword born before him, Attended by Clifford, Northumberland, Weſtmorland, Exeter, in their Robes.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: My Lords, look where the ſturdy Rebel ſits.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Look where your King is ſeated, Duke of Lancaſter,
What ſay you? will you reſign in peace the Crown
To him whoſe right it is, Richard Plantagenet?
Or ſhall we force it from you by our Swords?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Let's tear the Crown from the Uſurpers head.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Sound but the Trumpets and the King will fly.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Peace, Sons.

sp.speaker: Hen
sp.l: Peace all of you, and hear your King.
Rebels, I fear all danger leſs than you do,
For I am better arm'd with innocence.
But I confeſs I do fear Civil War;
Not for my own, but for my peoples ſake,
I am afraid to ſhed the blood of Engliſh men,
But you indeed are bold in cruelty.
By which (oh Heaven!) judge whoſe is the Child
His who deſires to have it cut in peices,
Or mine, who ſtrive in tenderneſs to ſave it.
For my own part I fear no power, but Heaven,
Rebels may be ſucceſsful for a time,
And overturn all order, right, aud juſtice,
But Heaven does not let the world ſtand long
In that unnatural uneaſie poſture,
But ſoon put's all things in their proper places.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Thy own mouth, Henry, has pronounc'd thy doom.
Succeſsful Murder, and Rebellion,
Swell'd for two Generations of thy race
Over all right, and all that durſt oppoſe 'em;
But Heaven in thee has dryed up the black ſtream,
And made it ſuch a Brook all trample over it.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I've oft been told by thee, my Grand-father
Depos'd his King.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: And I did tell thee truth.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Cannot a King adopt an Heir?

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: VVhat then?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Did not King Richard to my Grand-father
Reſign the Crown in open Parliament?

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Did not thy Grand-father compel him to it
By force of Arms? and then the Parliament,
To their eternal ſhame, if not Damnation,
Flatter'd the wicked fortunate Uſurper.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: But ſay, the King had done it unconſtrain'd,
He cou'd not give away another's right.
Henry uſurp'd the right of the next Heirs.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: My Conſcience tells me that my Title is weak.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: How, Sir, will you revolt from your own ſelf?
Who will ſtand by you then?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Clifford, thou dyeſt,
If thou permit'ſt not Henry to reſign.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Let Henry give his Title to the Crown,
He ſhall not give my Title to revenge.
May the ground gape and ſwallow me alive,
When e're I kneel to him who kill'd my Father.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Ho! there within.—

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: I am prepar'd for you.

div.stage: War. ſtamps, and enter Souldiers of his ſide. Cl. does the ſame and enter Souldiers on his ſide; as they are going to fight, King Henry interpoſes.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Hold! hold! my Lords: Oh! let not Blood be ſhed;
Let us not make a Shambles of this place.
Pray hear me all; I find my Title's weak,
And to defend it were to fight with Juſtice,
Beſides, there lyes already on my head
The Blood of Richard, murder'd by my Grand-father,
And I'd be loth to add my peoples Blood;
For ſaving which, hear this propoſal from me,
I have been King theſe eight and thirty years,
And many Intereſts muſt grow to mine
That you can never tear me from the Throne,
But you will ſet a thouſand Veins a bleeding,
Then let me reign in quiet all my life,
And when I'm dead, Plantagenet be King

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: I approve of it, and on that condition
I ſwear to be King Henry's faithful Vaſſal.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And not to ſeek the Throne by Arms or Treaſon?

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Never whilſt King Henry lives.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Then I entail
The Crown to thee and to thy Heirs for ever.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: The Devil to him, and to his Heirs for ever.
VVhat have you done?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Good to himſelf and England.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: VVrong to his Son, his Subjects, and himſelf.

sp.speaker: Ex.
sp.l: VVhy ſigh you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: For my poor Son I've wrong'd.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: You have not wrong'd him, you have wholly freed him
From all the Vengeance due to Uſurpation.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Oh! Henry, if thy Father's Soul did ſee
Thy baſeneſs, it wou'd torture him in Heaven.
Plantagenet, when that great Monarch liv'd,
Thou durſt have ſooner let into thy Soul
Ten thouſand Devils than a Traytrous Thought:
Farewel degenerate faint-hearted King,
May'ſt thou be beat in War, and ſcorn'd in Peace.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Sons, head the Troops before the Palace Gate,
Leſt furious Clifford ſhou'd do ſome raſh thing.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Here comes the Queen.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And with her my poor Son.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: She appears big with Thunder and with Lightning:
Expect a Tempeſt quickly, Sir, but ſlight it.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Are the news true? can it be poſſible
That you have diſinherited your Son?
And given your Crown to Trayterous Plantagenet?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The Crown is his, I have no Title to it,
But what is founded on Rebellion,
The murder of a King and uſurpation.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Then haſt thou not the ſpirit of a King,
Nor of a Father, timerous mean VVretch,
To let a Crew of Rebels hector thee
Out of a Crown, nay out of thy own Son?
For thou muſt think thou haſt no Title to him,
Or thou'dſt not diſinherit him unnaturally.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: My Love, I do not diſinherit him;
For what I give away is not his right;
And if I ſhould entail another's right on him,
I ſhou'd entail Heaven's Vengeance on his head.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Who ſays the Crown's not yours?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I am convinc'd
By powerful Arguments.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: By Pikes and Swords.
Had I been here when thou mad'ſt this Agreement,
The Souldiers ſhou'd have toſt me on their Pikes,
E're I'd have ſtoop'd to ſuch unnatural bafeneſs.
Oh! how came thee and I in Marriage joyn'd!
For I am Fire, thou art weak floating Water,
Driven by the breath of Rebels any way.
Wou'd I had dy'd a Maid, and never ſeen thee;
At leaſt had never born thee ſuch a Son.
Oh! my ſweet Son, thou art no more a Prince,
Becauſe thy Father is no more a King.
He has undone himſelf, and thee, and all of us.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I am a Prince, and I will be a King.
Father, you cannot diſinherit me;
You may beſtow your Kingdom whil'ſt you live;
But when you are dead it is not yours, but mine.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My Son, he ſhall not diſinherit thee.
I have men here to guard me from theſe Rebels,
And Troops elſe-where to conquer 'em, and puniſh 'em.
And I will make my Son a Glorious Prince;
Whil'ſt thou, tame Prince, ſhalt be a ſlave to Traytors:
Made to aſſiſt in conquering thy ſelf,
And then in digging thy own Sepulchre;
For Rebels will not do their work by halves.
Though thou art but the ſhadow of a King,
Rebels will tremble at a Royal Shadow,
And they'll be forc'd to kill thee, if 'tis poſſible,
To make thee a more dead thing than thou art.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Oh! my dear Love, talk not ſo harſhly to me.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I will be harſher in my deeds than words.
For from this moment I divorce my ſelf
For ever from thy Bed, thou art no King,
And thou ſhalt have no Sons of me to ruine;
I ſcorn to be the Mother of a Slave.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Poor Queen, how love and pity for my Son
Set her a-raging, as they ſet me grieving?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Add her ambition to her love and pity,
For that has no ſmall ſhare in her diſturbance.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: I know ſhe's raiſing Forces in the North,
My Lord of Warwick, do you keep the King,
And ſtay to raiſe what Force you can in London,
VVhilſt I will to the North, and ſo between us
VVe'll wall her in, and keep that fire from ſpreading.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Pray, my Lords, do, I will aſſiſt you both
Againſt my ſelf, I'll do to others right,
Though on my ſelf I ſure deſtruction bring,
E're I'll be wicked, I will be no King.

div.head: ACT. III.
Scene a Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: HOW has this Woman charm'd theſe men together,
No leſs than twenty thouſand? a vaſt Army!
All my Troops here will ſcarcely make five thouſand,
Then ſhe is gotten between me and London;
That I can no way join the Earl of Warwick,
Nor can he poſſibly come time enough
To my aſſiſtance; I am in a ſtrait.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I think not, Sir, brave men are never in a ſtrait
When they have Arms and Liberty to ſight.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: I ſhou'd ſlight odds, if the Enemy were French,
But now our preſent Enemies are Engliſh,
Made of the ſame brave ſtuff as we our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: But ſuch brave ſtuff as we have ſoundly beaten,
And ſuch as are conducted by a Woman.
And men ne're think of fighting under Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: I've ſent your Brother George to raiſe ſome Troops,
I hop'd he might have been with me er'e now;
But I muſt take my fortune now, the Enemy
Approaches us—bring in my dear Boy Rutland.

div.stage: Enter Rutland, and a Prieſt his Tutor.
div.l: My Darling, let me kiſs thee e're I go,
I know not if I 'ere ſhall ſee thee more;
If I ſhould fall under the numerous Enemy,
I leave thee to the care of thy three Brothers,
All valiant men, and ſome of 'em I hope
Will be great men, be Kings; I charge 'em all
On my laſt bleſſing to take care of thee,
My pretious Darling, as of their own Souls.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Why do you talk thus, Sir? you make me weep,
If you muſt dye, I hope I ſhall dye with you;
I had rather dye with you than live a King.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Sweet Boy, farewell my Soul;—here take the Boy
And guard him ſafely in the ſtrong dark Vault,
And if things prove worſe than I hope they will,
Convey him ſafely to our next Garriſon,
And give his Brothers notice of his flight.

div.stage: [Ex. Pl. Ed. Rich, one way, another Rutl. with a Guard.
An Allarm, ſhouts of Victory, the Scene continues. Enter Clifford and his Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Purſue, purſue, purſue, and give no quarter,
I charge you do not ſpare Man, Woman, or Child.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Oh! whither ſhall I fly? how ſhall I eſcape?
Ah! Clifford comes! and no one's here to guard me.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Ha! have I found one of Plantagenet's Brats?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Oh! now I ſhall be murder'd! hold, my Lord,
Hear me but ſpeak one word before I dye.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: What canſt thou ſay, fond Boy, that's worth my hearing?

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I'd only beg you to regard your ſelf;
You are a valiant man, I am a Boy;
Stain not your fame by killing a poor Boy,
I wou'd not for your own ſake you ſhou'd do it;
For I love gallant men, and I love you;
Though you are my Enemy, becauſe you are gallant.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Away you inſinuating, flattering boy,
Who taught you this Hypocriſie? your Prieſt?
Give o're, give o're! for were there in thy Voice
Celeſtial Harmony, my Father's Blood
Has ſtop'd the paſſage where the ſound ſhou'd enter.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: I did not ſhed his Blood.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Thy Father did.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Then ſight my Father, that will get you honour.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Shou'd I kill thee, thy Father, all thy Brothers,
Nay ſhou'd I dig up thy Fore-father's Graves,
And hang their rotten Coſſins up in Chains,
My rage wou'd not be quench'd.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: That's very ſtrange;
VVhy ſhou'd your fury burn againſt the innocent?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: I kill thee out of hatred to thy kind,
As I wou'd do a Toad, or a young Serpent.

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Hear me but one word more, dear, brave, Lord Clifford;
You have a Son, for his ſake pity me,
Leſt as you kill me for my Father's faults,
Juſt Heaven ſhou'd deſtroy your Son for yours,
And he be miſerably kill'd as I am.
Then, Oh! for your Son's ſake give me my life,
And for my Father's faults keep me in Priſon,
And kill me whenſoever I offend you.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Thou wilt be an offence to me in living.
Whilſt any of thy curſed Fathers race
Live upon Earth, I live on Earth?—then dye—

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: Oh! ſhall I have no pity at your hands?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Such pity as my Rapiers point affords!

sp.speaker: Rut.
sp.l: May'ſt thou ne're get more ſame than by this deed;
Oh my poor Father! Oh! my death will kill him.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Ho! take the body up, and carry it after me,
I'll make a preſent of it to his Father.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: All's loſt, my men by numbers are devour'd,
Or fly like Ships before the ſtormy wind.
My Sons have bravely fought, but all in vain,
They only ſwim like Swans againſt the Tide,
And are born down by over-matching Waves,
And I am very faint and cannot flie;
But had I ſtrength, I'm on all ſides enclos'd,
The Sands are numbred that make up my life,
See! the bloody Clifford comes! then here I fall!

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Ha! have I found thee proud Plantagenet.
What tumbled Phaethon from thy ſhining Chariot,
And made an Evening at thy higheſt Noon?
Oh Father! from the joys above deſcend,
And ſhare with me the pleaſure of Revenge,
Or elſe by high revenge I'll climb to thee.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Thou bloody raging Clifford, do thy worſt;
I'd ſcorn to ask thee mercy hadſt thou any,
But thou haſt none, then come with all thy Multitudes.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: So Cowards ſight when they can fly no farther,
So Pigeons peck the Falcon's piercing Talons,
So deſperate Thieves breathe curſes at the Officers.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Haſt thou the impudence to charge a Prince
With cowardize, who made thee baſely fly?
Call to thy memory S. Albans Battel.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: I do, then didſt thou kill my brave old Father.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: And now wou'd thee, wert thou not back't with multitudes.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: I will try that; ſtand of, and do not touch him,
Unleſs I fall; then cut him all to pieces.
I will not loſe revenge; yet I will give him
So much revenge to kill me if he can.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: I thank thee for the kindneſs, 'tis a great one.

div.stage: They Fight, Plantagenet is diſarm'd and thrown.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Now wilt thou yield that I have fairly conquer'd thee?

div.stage: As Cl. is lifting up his arm to kill him, Enter the Queen.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Hold valiant Clifford! hold!—I wou'd prolong
The Traytors life to ſcorn him, trample on him:
Are you the man that wou'd be King of England?
Are you the man that revell'd in the Parliament?
Sat in your Sovereign's Throne, and did believe
Your breath cou'd blow his Crown from off his head?
Where are your Meſs o'Sons to back you now?
Your wanton Edward, and your luſty George,
Your ugly valiant Dick, that crookback Prodigy?
And with the reſt, where is your darling Rutland?

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: My heart miſgives me, where is he indeed?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ask Clifford.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Oh! thou haſt not butcher'd, Clifford,
The innocent Boy?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: On that young tender morſell
My greedy vengeance ſtaid a while it's ſtomach,
Till it cou'd dine on thee, and all thy Sons.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: See! I have ſtain'd a Napkin in the blood,
That valiant Clifford with his Rapier's point
Made iſſue from the boſome of thy darling,
And bring it thee to wipe away thy tears.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: She-wolf of France! or rather cruel Tygreſs,
For woman thou art none; women are ſoft,
Gentle and pitiful, but thou art cruel,
Oh! ten times more than an Hyrcanian Tygreſs.
There is a Boy that thinks thou art his Mother;
But ſurely thou didſt never bear a Child,
For thou woud'ſt ſomething know a Parents love,
And have ſome natural touch of pitie in thee,
And not have drain'd the life-blood of a Child
To bid his Father wipe his eyes withal.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I therefore did it to increaſe thy ſorrow:
I know a Parent's love, and thy fond love,
And all the myſteries of thy haughty heart;
I knew that thou woud'ſt Barricado it
Againſt the loſſes of a Crown and Life,
With Iron-barrs of ſtubborneſs and pride,
But oh! this blood like Oyl will ſink into it;
Theſe Crimſon threads will lead tormenting grief
Into the inmoſt lodgings of thy Soul,
And leſt this Napkin be too ſoft a thing
I have within an Engine that ſhall ſqueeze
Thy ſoul into thy eyes. Bring Rutland's Body.
Now thou haſt drunk the liquour, take the cup.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Oh! my ſweet Boy!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ah! this is Muſick to me!
This is the part thou mean'ſt I ſhou'd have plaid,
If thy accurſed Treaſons had ſucceeded.
But that my Tragedy muſt have been deeper,
And bloodier far; thou mean'ſt I ſhoud have wept
For a loſt Kingdom, Husband, and a Son.

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Yes, and I do not doubt but my three Sons,
Heaven's vengeance, and the curſes of all England
Shortly will make thee weep for loſs of all 'em.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I'll ſpoil thy prophecying; give me a ſword.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: I'll pierce him firſt, there's for my Fathers blood.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: There for the horrid ills thou threatneſt to me.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: There for the ills he brought upon the Kingdome,

sp.speaker: Pl.
sp.l: Open thy gate of mercy gratious Heaven!—.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Now take his head once fill'd with lofty thoughts,
And ſet it on a lofty pinacle.—

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: No tydings of my Father? I am troubled!

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Brother, I've news!

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: What of our valiant Father?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Oh no! I cannot hear what is become of him.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: What are your news then?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: They are not very good;
A Meſſenger is come from the Earl of Warwick,
Who tell's us he is marching to our aid,
But leaving a ſtrong party with Lord Cobham,
To guard the King, and all the Southern parts,
They chanc'd to meet with ſome of the Queen's Troops.
And whether the Kings Coldneſs numm'd his keepers,
Or whether terror of the Warlike Queen,
Whoſe armies and ſucceſs each hour encreaſe
Or of the inexorable cruel Clifford,
It is not known, but my Lord Cobham's men
Look'd on the ſhining Valour of the Enemy,
Like ſleepy Owles on day, and fell beneath it.
That they were all deſtroyed, and Henry fled,
With the Victorious Troops to joyn the Queen;
That the Earl of Warwick now wants ſtrength to fight her.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: This is ill news indeed! what ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Hee deſires you to haſte away with ſpeed,
To meet ten thouſand men marching from Wales,
Rais'd by your intereſt there to whom he ſent
To joyn his Troops if poſſible to morrow.
Which they may do, if you will haſten 'em.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: They ſhall not want for that, I'll go this inſtant.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Pray do not fail, for all our Lives, and Fortunes
Are ſet on this one caſt.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I'll ſpur away.
Which way go you?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I'll to the Earl of Warwick.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: My Horſe, my Horſe, I muſt ride for a Kingdom.

div.stage: Enter Lady Eleanor Butler in a riding dreſs.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: My Love!—or a fair Viſion! if a Viſion
Tell me, leſt I embrace thee into a Dew.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Yes, I am that fond ſhe who gave Lord Edward
The lovelyeſt, braveſt, but the moſt inconſtant
Of all mankind my hand and heart for ever.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Then I am that fond he, will loſe a Kingdom
Rather than one hours pleaſure with my Love,
And ſo farewell a Kingdom for an hour.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: I heard you were ſurrounded by the Queens
Numerous Troops, and in exceeding danger;
And I cou'd have no quiet, till I came
And ſhar'd your deſtiny what e're it was.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh! it was kindly charitably done,
To ſpeak the truth, mine is a ſcurvy deſtiny,
The Enemy is in my Father's Caſtle,
And I've no Beds of Down, on Golden Bed-ſteads
Under plum'd Canopies, t'embrace my Love in;
My Deſtiny wil be to lye to night
On ſome Straw-bed, under ſome low thatch'd Roof,
And thou ſhalt ſhare it; what if the chil wind
Blow on us? it will make us lye the cloſer;
Or what if we ſhou'd lye on the cold Earth?
It was our Grandſire Adam's Bridal Bed,
'Twas there he gave the ſtart to all mankind.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Fye, Fye, ſuch thoughts as theſe at ſuch a time?
When you have a Life and Kingdom to look after.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: A thouſand Lives and Kingdoms are in thee,
Whilſt the Enemies tall fortune ſtalks about
In darkneſs, like a blinded Polyphem;
We will creep under it into a Cottage
Of ſome of my own faithful Tenants here,
And ſafely ſteal delight, like cunning Mariners,
Pilfring the hold out of the reach of ſhot.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Have you a mind then to be kill'd or taken?
The Woods are all full of the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Shou'd all the Trees turn men, and the Graſs Pikes,
I will not ſtir from hence, till I've enjoy'd thee.
My crooked Brother Richard like a Hook
Pull'd me away from thee the other night,
For which I'll lay a double Tax on this.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Though I am but your Wife in hopes and promiſes,
So great an Empire have you over me,
My heart wou'd not refuſe you any Tax,
Did not your ſelf run danger in the gathering.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: There is no danger, every Cottager
In all theſe parts will hang e're he'll betray me;
Then let the loſs of the laſt opportunity
Make us ſo wiſe, to uſe this whilſt we have it.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Pray do not ask me.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Pray do not deny me.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: You will be taken.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: No, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: But if you ſhou'd?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: No matter if Thieves come,
When we have put our Money out to uſe.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: You are a ſtrange man.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: And you are a ſweet woman.
Come, come away.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Well now, if miſchief happen
Do not blame me.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: There can no miſchief happen,
Like loſing this moſt bleſſed opportunity,
Then come along,—along—

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Oh! that I cou'd not.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Away, away, I ſay.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Well—ſince I muſt—

div.stage: Enter Souldiers dragging Country-men. Scene a Cottage.

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.l: Where is your Money, Rogues? confeſs, you Rogues.

sp.speaker: 1 Coun.
sp.l: Indeed, Sir, I am a very poor man,
I get my living by my labour, Sir,
And I have nothing but from hand to mouth.

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.l: You lye, you Rogue, you lye, I know the tricks
Of all you Rogues; when e're your King wants Money,
Then you are poor, you cannot pay your Taxes;
But if the Swords of Rebels plow the Nation
Then you have Bags, and you can bring 'em out
Like Baggs of Seed, and ſow 'em all for Crops
To maintain Rogues that fight againſt your King;
Nay for that uſe can pawn your Pots and Kettels,
But now for us you cannot find a Farthing.

sp.speaker: 2 Coun.
sp.l: Indeed, Sir, you ſhou'd have it, if I had it,
VVith all my heart.

sp.speaker: 2 Soul.
sp.l: You lye, you Rogue, you lye.
I know this Rogue, he is one of the damn'd Rebels,
Plantagenet's chief Tenants, a rich Fellow;
You have no Money for the King's Souldiers,
But you had Money to fit out your Son
A Trooper, Sirrah, to fight for Rebellion.

sp.speaker: 3 Soul.
sp.l: Oh Rogue!

sp.speaker: 2 Soul.
sp.l: I knew his Son, and kill'd the Dog.

sp.speaker: 2. Co.
sp.l: Oh! wretched me! he was my only Son.

sp.speaker: 1. So.
sp.l: Come take the Rogue and hang him on that tree,
Unleſs he preſently confeſs his Money.

sp.speaker: 2. Cou.
sp.l: Oh! Sir, I will confeſs! I will confeſs.

sp.speaker: 3. Sou.
sp.l: Then you have money, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: 2. Coun.
sp.l: Yes, a little.

sp.speaker: 1 Sou.
sp.l: A little! Oh! you Rogue! juſt now you had none.
You have a little too?

sp.speaker: 1 Coun.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, a little.

sp.speaker: 2 So.
sp.l: And where's your little Money? quickly! quickly!

sp.speaker: 2 Cou.
sp.l: Mine is buried here, under my Hearth.

sp.speaker: 1 So.
sp.l: Come digg and find it.

sp.speaker: 2 Co.
sp.l: Oh! undone!

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.l: Digg, Digg.

sp.speaker: 2 Soul.
sp.l: Where is your Money, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: 1 Cou.
sp.l: In my Cow-houſe
Under the Dung.

sp.speaker: 2 Soul.
sp.l: Go, Sirrah! go and fetch it.

sp.speaker: 2 Cou.
sp.l: Here's all my money! Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Soul.
sp.l: Here all, you Rogue?
Sirrah! you lye! you have ten times as much.
Do not I know you a fat Bacon Rogue,
That have been ſmoking in Plantagenet's Chimney,
Theſe forty years? Sirrah! I know your purſe
Cut's a foot thick, of Reechy golden fat.

sp.speaker: 2 Cou.
sp.l: Indeed here's every penny, that I have.

sp.speaker: 1 So.
sp.l: Do you think, Sirrah, we'll be chous'd o'this faſhion?
We have hang'd half the people in your Country,
For offering to put ſuch tricks upon us;
And therefore have a care.

sp.speaker: 2 Coun.
sp.l: Oh! I'll confeſs!
I'm an old man, and my only Son is kill'd.
And now I care not what becomes o' me,
I'll ſhew you all I have; there it lies buried
Uuder yon Oak.

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.l: Go, Sirrah, go and fetch it.

sp.speaker: 1. Cou.
sp.l: Here's all I have been getting forty years.
Pray ſpare me a little for my two poor Daughters.

sp.speaker: 1. So.
sp.l: How has the Daughters? we ſhall have more ſport.

sp.speaker: All 3. So.
sp.l: Hay! for the Daughters! Hay for the Daughters.

sp.speaker: 1. Co.
sp.l: Ah! my poor Daughters!

div.stage: Enter the Souldiers chaſing two Country Girles, who cry, help! help! their Father runns after 'em weeping: they all rnn over the Stage. After cries within.
Enter the Souldiers with Money baggs, dragging the Countrymen. Scene continues.

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: So now you ſtognes, how do you like Rebellion?
You were a Couple of ſeditious Rogues,
That us'd at Ale-houſes to pay for all
That rail'd againſt the King, and Government.
Now had not you better have Plowed, and Carted,
And pay'd your Taxes honeſtly and quietly,
Then have your Money ſeiz'd, your Daughters raviſh'd,
Your Sons knock'd o' the head, and your ſelves hang'd,
As you ſhall be?

sp.speaker: 1 Coun.
sp.l: Oh! Sir! I hope not ſo,
Now you have promis'd us.

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.l: You impudent Doggs,
Did not you ſwear Allegiance to your King?
Yet break your Oaths to him? and do you expect,
We ſhou'd keep Verbal promiſes with you?

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: This Country belongs, Sirrah, to your Landlord;
And we have orders to take all the Money,
Burn all the Houſes, and hang all the people.
We have obey'd our orders yet, and will.

div.stage: The Scene is drawn, and there appears Houſes and Towns burning, Men and Women hang'd upon Trees, and Children on the tops of Pikes.

sp.speaker: 1 Coun.
sp.l: Oh Heaven! have mercy on us! have mercy on us!

sp.speaker: 2 Coun.
sp.l: Oh Heaven! have mercy on us! have mercy on us!

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.l: Now Rogues, how do you like Rebellion?

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: Come hang 'em whilſt there is a Tree to ſpare,
They are almost all beſpoke.

sp.speaker: Scout.
sp.l: To Armes, to Armes, Warwick is coming.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.l: Warwick! Arme, Arm, Arm.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Oh horrid ſpectacle! See here, my Lord!

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: The Queen is planting in your Fathers Lands
An Orchard for the Devil.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I will dung this Orchard
With the blood of thoſe that planted it,
I have a Spirit in this crooked Trunck
Stands like a keeper in a hollow Tree,
Ready with bended bow to ſhoot fat Deer,
And down goe's thou, thy Henry, all thy Race.
I'll not leave killing, 'till I've built my Father
A monument of Bones and Sculls of Enemies
That ſhall o'relook th' Aegyptian Pyramids.
Oh that my Brother Edward now were come!

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Till his Troops come we cannot fight the Enemy,
For they are above thirty thouſand ſtrong,
And we ſcarce twelve.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What do I ſee! I think
I ſee him there! pray look, my Lord, and tell me.
Now I am ſure 'tis he! for there's a Woman:
Oh! we are ruin'd! for I will be damn'd,
If he has not been with her all this Night.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: He durſt not do it, durſt not ſerve me ſo.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I ſee my Brother and my Lord of Warwick,
Retire.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: My Lord of Warwick.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Yes my Lord;
Where are your men?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: My Lord, I muſt confeſs,
I've been to night a happy, but great ſinner.
Starting to gallop for the Crown, my deſtiny
Flung in my way brighter temptations,
Than were all Atalanta's Golden Balls,
That had it coſt a Kingdom and my life,
I cou'd not but have ſtoop'd to take 'em up.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: 'Tis well, muſt all the glory we have div'd for
In Seas of blood, be melted in a kiſs,
And ſwallowed down like Cleopatra's pearl
In one ſweet draught?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: So you have ſerv'd me well.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: And do you thus revenge our Fathers blood?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: But what revenge ſhall I have for the ruin,
That I am like to ſuffer in your ſervice?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Fear not.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I do not fear, I know which way
I can repair my ſelf; in Henry's ſervice
I can have greatneſs with less pains, and dangr,
Than I muſt take in yours to be undone.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: You will not leave me?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: You firſt left your ſelf,
And left me too.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I beg your pardon for it,
Who, now my Fathers murderd, am your King.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: You are my King, but King of my own making,
And I, like Heaven, repent I've made a Creature'
Who for the Apple of a rowling Eye,
Will loſe a World: But I'll ſecure my ſhare of it.
I will go make Henry a King again,
And tumble you again into a ſubject.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: You will not ſure, my Lord!

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I ſwear I will.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh but you cannot do it.

sp.speaker: War.
