sp.l: I'll try that.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: You can at moſt but make Henry a Tyrant,
For I am lawful King.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Oh! I'll give Henry
My Sword, and do you keep your lawfulneſs,
Then try which of you will be King of England.
I ne're found Conſcience or in Prieſt, or Layman
So firm at anchor, but a golden Ax
Wou'd cut the Cable, or ſucceſs cou'd weigh it,
And ſet the Conſcience ſwimming with the Tyde.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Oh! I cou'd tear my ſleſh! muſt we be ruin'd
For a fair Toy?—but I will not be ruin'd.
For I will ſeek the Kingdom for my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Brother, 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Brother, it ſhall be ill,
Exceeding ill with you, and very quickly.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Hold! I command you both hear me one word.
Know I have only made a Tryal of you,
For I have brought the Troops that you deſir'd,
I march'd 'em hither with ſuch expedition,
Their front encounter'd here the front of day.
Nay more, I've brought my Brother and his Troops,
Both Armies are not half a mile from hence;
And here my Brother is: Brother, come hither.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I heard of our great Fathers ſad misfortunes
And came to his revenge with all the ſpeed
A hungry wretch wou'd do to a great feaſt,
Where there were many gueſts, and he far off.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Now my good faithful Friends, what think you both?
Now, Warwick, will you make Henry a King?
And, Brother, will you make your ſelf a King?
I was inform'd of what I have diſcover'd
That you, good Brother, ſought to be a King;
And Warwick to command him, who is King;
And him you cannot Govern, you will ruin.
Henry is govern'd by the Queen and Clifford
And ſo becauſe there is no room for Rule,
You fight for us to make us all your Vaſſals.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Who durſt ſay this of me?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: And what bold Villain
Durſt give you ſuch a Character of me?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh! you are angry, I'm inform'd the truth.
If they be Villains, who durſt tell me this,
Then what are you, who durſt to my own face
Threaten to do all this?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: It was all paſſion.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Nothing but paſſion.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Brother, you are wrong'd,
Or in cold blood you are as bad as this;
You act the undermining Polititian,
A King is a ſtrong Tower on a high Rock,
And it is dangerous to ſtorm him openly;
So at a mighty diſtance they break ground
And caſt up earth, that is by ſubtle tricks
They raiſe the dirty crow'd, and behind them
They lie ſecure from Royal battery.
There if they find any unguarded place,
About the King, they uſe it moſt unmercifully.
My heart to beauty always lies too open,
And that infirmitie thou giveſt no quarter;
Though thou who cenſureſt me, becauſe ſometimes,
I ſhed ſome vacant hours among fair Women,
Wou'dſt ſhed the blood, or of thy Friend or King,
Or if thy Father, were he now alive,
To gain a Crown, for there is thy chief Luſt.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: That is a Cruel cenſure.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: But a true one,
Who ſtabbs my Name, wou'd ſtab my Perſon too,
Did not the Hangman's Ax lye in his way,
And no man care's to ſtumble upon that.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Well, Sir, I have ſo long gone clad in Steel,
I have forgot to kneel; but yet my Spirit,
More ſtubborn than my ſinews, bends to you,
And beggs your pardon for my too raſh paſſion,
For 'twas no more, and there appear'd occaſion;
Though you it ſeems kindled the fire o' purpoſe
To ſhew us by the light of it our faults.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Nay, I will own after the days Fatigues,
I fell into an ambuſcade of beauty,
Where ignorant of what befell my Father,
And deep in Love, I lay ſome hours laſt night;
And which of you wou'd not have done the ſame?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: All of us wou'd, and, Sir, I humbly beg you
Think my wild paſſion was the Woman in me,
And I've enjoy'd my Woman, as you yours.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: My Lord, I know you wou'd enjoy your Woman,
I mean your Miſtreſs, for you have a Miſtreſs,
And you, who threatned to revolt from me;
Becauſe ſome moments, which were due to buſineſs,
I gave away to Beauty, and to Love,
Had almoſt at S. Albans given away
Our victory, to a Woman that abhorr'd you.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Yes, my Lord, I was inform'd the ſtory.
You woo'd her, over her dead Husband's Body,
Till you were almoſt taken by the Enemy.
I do not know her Name, I never pry
Into your pleaſures, though you cenſure mine.
But thou in Chaſtity, wou'dſt ſeem a Scipio.
Know, that the Woman that thou ſaw'ſt me with,
Was thy own Whore.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Yes, thy own poor Whore,
A Peaſant's dirty Daughter, whom thou keep'ſt,
By whom thou haſt a little tawny Baſtard,
Whom I o' purpoſe brought to ſhew thy Faults,
In th' eyes, where thou haſt often ſeen thy face.
This is the Lady.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Curſed treacherous jade!

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Now, Sirs, what think you?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, give me leave
To intercede for 'em, I ſee ſhame covers 'em,
And to great minds no puniſhment like ſhame.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Sir, not for mine, but for my Father's ſake
Pardon my Errours and accept my Service,
That I may aid you to revenge his Blood.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Sir, not for mine, but for the Kingdoms ſake,
Pardon my Errours and accept my ſervice,
For I by placing you in the Engliſh Throne
Shall place the Engliſh Throne above the World.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Riſe both of you, I freely pardon you,
And yet methinks it is unequal uſage
A King ſhou'd pardon all the faults of Subjects,
And Subjects pardon nothing in their King;
When a King's crown'd, he is not deifyed,
When he puts on the Royal Robes, he does not
Therefore put of th' Infirmities of man.
I own I have my faults, and ſo have you,
You ſee I have convinc'd you, and I did it
That you might leave your faults and pardon mine;
Or if you kept your faults to part with me;
For if my Lord of Warwick does deſign
By all his Service only to enſlave me,
I ſhall loſe nothing by his leaving me,
I can but be a Slave when I am conquer'd,
And if my Brother Richard has worſe ends—

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Oh! Sir, no more, unleſs you do deſign
I ſhou'd rip up my Breaſt to ſhew my heart—

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Sir, I'll deſire no farther pardon of you,
Till I have writ it in your Enemies Blood,
And pawn'd my Life and Fortune for my Loyalty.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Our Friendſhip then is ſtronger for this breach,
Now let us bend our talk to our Affairs,
On the ſad tidings of my Father's death,
Which I but lately heard, I ſent Commiſſioners
To Henry to demand the Crown of him
According to the Oath he made in Parliament.
They are here!—what tydings? Peace, or War?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: War.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: War.

sp.speaker: 1 Com.
sp.l: Th' Amazon Queen drags Henry to the Battel.
He fain would keep his Oath, but ſhe'll not ſuffer him.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I'm glad of it, I would not for a Kingdom
Peace ſhou'd chain up that Bloody Maſtiff Clifford,
And keep him ſafe from the edge of our keen Swords.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: You wrong the Beaſt to give that name to Clifford,
An Engliſh Maſtiff ſcorns to bite a Child.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Now let us march to meet the Enemy,
This day decides who ſhall be King of England,
The right is ours.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And Juſtice will prevail,
Since Right and Merit both are in the Scale.

div.head: ACT. IV.
div.stage: Enter King Henry, the Queen, Prince, Clifford.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: DAmn your unlucky Planets, pray, Sir, get you
Out of the Battel, 'tis impoſſible
For men to fight the malice of your Planets.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He tells you true, Sir, Victory will never
Come where you are.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Victory will not come
Where Perjury is, you make me break my Oath.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: You ought not to have ſworn ſo ill an Oath.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Father, you cannot give away my Right,
I'll rather loſe my life than my Inheritance.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Spoke like a Prince.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Oh! Boy, if thou didſt know
What a Crown was, thou wou'dſt be more content,
If I ſhou'd leave thee no Inheritance,
But the Example of my vertuous deeds;
I wiſh my Father had left me no more.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Oh! damn all this!—come, let us to the Battel.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Oh! how this Fellow curſes? he accuſes
My Stars for my misfortunes, when his Curſes
Wound all my Men, and poyſon the Enemies ſhot.
Wou'd I were dead if it were Heav'ns good will!
For I am very weary of this World.
Troubleſome folly governs all this World.
Men live her Vaſſals, and they dye her Martyrs.
Oh! happy he who in an humble ſtate
Only attends on Nature's eaſie buſineſs,
And brings white heirs down to a quiet Grave,
Falling to earth, as gently as the Snow,
sp.stage: Alarm! Enter a Son bearing his Father.
sp.l: Here comes a wretch laden, as he believes,
With happy Fortune, 'tis with bloudy folly,
And Heaven has carv'd Fool on his breaſt with wounds.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.l: Who e're thou art thy life has coſt me dear,
But I'll repay my ſelf out of thy Gold;
If thou haſt any; with the hopes of that
I took ſuch pains to kill thee. And yet I
Who plunder thee, may be compel'd e're Night,
To give my life, and plunder to another.
What's this? Oh! Heaven! I have kill'd my Father.
Oh Father pardon me, I did not know thee.
I was in London preſt to ſerve the King,
And thou the Earl of Warwick's ſervant preſt,
To fight on th' other ſide, and ſo unknown
We met and Fought; and ſo unknown I kill'd thee.
Oh from thy Boſom I will waſh away,
With tears, the marks of this unnatural Crime.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Oh piteous ſpectacle! Oh ſad confuſions!
What horrid errours, and unnatural ills
Our horrid and unnatural war produces!
Poor wretch, didſt thou want tears I cou'd ſupply thee.

div.stage: Enter a Father bearing his Son.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Thou that ſo ſtoutly haſt reſiſted me;
Give me thy gold, if thou haſt any gold,
For I have bought it with a hundred blows.
Ha! let me ſee, is this my Enemy?
Ah no, my Son, I've kill'd my only Son.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Ah woe on woe, Heaven ſtop theſe bloudy miſchiefs,
Though by the Death of me and all my Race.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.l: Oh I have ta'ne his life who gave me mine.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: Oh! I've kill'd him for whom I wou'd have dyed.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.l: How will my Mother for my Fathers death
Take on with me?

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: How will my mourning Wife,
Accuſe me of the ſlaughter of my Son?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: How will my people charge all this on me?

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.l: I'll bear thee hence and weep; but fight no more.

sp.speaker: Fath.
sp.l: I'll bear thee hence and weep; but kill no more,
Except my ſelf with ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Oh! poor men!
Here is a King more woful than you all;
For you grieve for your ſelves, I for you all.
Oh you, who when you ſuffer by your Kings,
Think to mend all by War, and by Rebellion!
See here, your ſad miſtakes! how dreadfully
You ſcourge your ſelves! learn here the greateſt Tyrant
Is to be choſe before the leaſt Rebellion.
And Oh you Kings, who let your people rule,
Till they have run themſelves into confuſion,
See here your gentleneſs is greateſt Tyranny!

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Fly, Father ſly, all's loſt, your Friends are fled.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: The day is loſt, and with the day, the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Where's Clifford?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I believe he's dead by this time,
I met him bleeding with a hundred wounds.
He all the day rowl'd like a ſiery meteor,
About the field, and burnt up men like reeds;
But now in lakes of blood his fire is quench'd.
Poſt you to Scotland with all haſte you can;
I will to France, to beg that Kings aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I go, but care not what becomes o' me.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Here burns my Candle out, that lighted Henry.
Warwick, and all Plantagenets three Sons.
And all King Henry's malicious Planets
With much ado to day have kill'd one man.
Henry's Stars ruine me and my fall him.
But his ſoft ſway made way for his deſtruction:
Oh! Henry, hadſt thou rul'd as Kings ſhou'd do,
Or as thy Father, or his Father did,
Theſe Summer ſlies had never ſprung to ſting thee,
Rebels you thrive, and may Rebellion thrive
That Rogues may cut your throats as you do ours,
The Ayr has got into my deadly wounds;
I am too faint to Fight or Fly; and Mercy,
I deſerve none, and will have none from Rebels,
I ſcorn to live by them who deſerve death.
Fate Guards the Scaffold, but ſhe hates the Office,
And will e're long let Rebels have their own.
I'm going! All you of Plantagenets Race—
My comfort is in death: I kill'd your Father.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Now the great cauſe is come to its deciſion:
Are any Troops gone to purſue the Queen?
On her tame Henry's fortune does depend
As the Seas ebb and ſlow does on the Moon.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Yes, I took care o' that.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: My chief care was,
To hunt the bloudy Clifford, but I cou'd not
Find him among the living, or the dead.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I thought you ſet death's mark ſo deep upon him,
Death cou'd not miſs him.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Fortune at us all
Play'd him to day, but when he was in danger,
Snatch'd him away again, as who ſhou'd ſay,
When I have loſt this card my game is gone.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Oh!—(Groans)

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: What Soul is that, that takes her heavy leave?
See who it is, and be he Friend or Enemy
Uſe him with mercy.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: No—'tis bloody Clifford.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Clifford?—

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Clifford?—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Clifford?—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: He's dead! oh that he had but life,
And ſenſe enough to ſee and hear, and know us!
That we might ſcoff him as he did our Father.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Damn him, he counterfeits to ſhun our taunts.
Clifford, you know me, ask me mercy, Clifford;
I am the Son of your dear Friend, Plantagenet,
I'll pity you, for you did pity Rutland.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: No anſwer? prithee ſwear as thou waſt wont.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: He's dead I'm certain, if he does not ſwear.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Damnation on you all—

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: He Curſes! he Curſes!

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then there is hopes of him.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: 'Twas his laſt Prayer:
Off with his Head, and place it on the pinacle,
Where the bold bloudy Slave durſt place our Fathers.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Now let the Trumpets proclaim Edward King.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: Long live Edward the fourth, King of England and France,
And Lord of Ireland.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Now march to London, Sir, I will to France,
About the Marriage you ſo much approved of
With the fair Lady Bona that Queens Siſter.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh! thou haſt made me much in love with her
And all Relations have encreaſ'd my Paſſion.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Sir, She's the faireſt Creature in the Woorld;
And in that Marriage you will not only
Have a fair bedfellow for your delight,
But that great King your friend for your ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I cannot marry better; haſte away.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I'm glad of this, I have ſecur'd my Miſtreſs.
Some days ago (as you commanded me)
I did diſpatch an Envoy to King Lewis,
To make the offer, and he ſeem'd unwilling,
Not knowing what th' event of War wou'd be.
But now I with the Sword, that conquer'd Henry,
Will go my ſelf Embaſſador, and try,
If a French King dare's deny any thing
To an Engliſh conquering Sword.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh! thou haſt given me
A Crown, give me this Beauty, and thou art
A God to me, thy gifts are all divine.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: My life too on his bounty does depend.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Is it in me to give you happineſs?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Yes, if a Father can beſtow a Daughter.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I ſhall be very proud, you will accept her.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I ſhall be very happy to attain her.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: She ſhall be yours, if the King give conſent.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: My Brother cou'd not have oblig'd me more
Than in this choice.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then ſhe's at his devotion.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Then I'm a happy man.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: The Earl of Warwick
Is the good Angel of our Family.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Of what ſtrange ſtuff ſo different from my Brothers
Am I made? they are all-over love;
I have appetite, but not one grain of Love.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Thou art not of a mould for love to grow in;
Men plant not flowers in a Kitchen garden.
Well, Brother, I create you Duke of Clarence.
You, Brother Richard, I make Duke of Glouceſter.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I do not like the Title, it is om inous.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: A fooliſh obſervation!—

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Royal Sir,
I'll take my leave.—

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Succeſs attend thy Embaſſy.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Succeſs attend your love—

div.stage: Enter Lady Grey, and her Woman.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: King Henry beaten? poor unfortunate King!
I and my Children are all ruin'd with him;
The conquerors will ſeize my Husbands lands.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Madam, the greateſt Conquerour is your Friend,
The Earl of Warwick, he'll preſerve your Fortune,
Yes, and advance 'em, if you'l give him leave.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Name not that inſolent great man, I hate him.

sp.speaker: Pa,
sp.l: Madam, the Earl of Warwick's coming up.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: He coming up? how knows he I am here?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: His Servants learnt it accidentally.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: So near fair Widow, and my beating pulſes,
And quivering fleſh give me no notice of it?
For the kind needle never fails to tremble
When it approaches it's beloved Pole.
What have you paid formality her wages,
And turn'd off that old Governeſs of Women?
Have you yet dryed your eyes, and drawn your Curtains?
Is the Son good enough to be admitted o you?
If ſo I hope his humble kindred may,
For I am near a-kin to him in heat.
In ſhort you ſhall be mine, if I can give
Others a Crown, I'll give my ſelf a wife.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: If you were ſerious, as I think you are not,
You give me a brave occaſion to revenge
My Husbands blood and your affronts to me,
By making you unhappy in a Wife.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Were you the firſt of Widows that talk'd thus,
I muſt confeſs I think 'twou'd damp my courage,
But when this is the conſtant language ſpoke
In the dark ſhady Land of Vailes and mourning,
Shou'd I be ſcar'd, I were as rank a fool
As the dull Heroe that ſhou'd leave a pleaſant
Country he conquer'd, 'cauſe the people ſpeak
A ſtrange odd Language; you are a conquer'd Province
And you may keep your Language and your Cuſtoms;
But I will have the Government and Tribute.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: My Lord, I have affairs of greater conſequence
Then this fond talk, and ſo your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: War
sp.l: So have not I, and therefore you ſhall ſtay.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: What do you mean my Lord?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I mean, my Lady,
To marry you this day, enjoy you this night.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: My Lord, I tell you plainly I do not love you.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: All's one, I tell you plainly I will have you.
I know you are a woman of great virtue,
And time will file away theſe rugged humours.
But if it do not, though your ſoul be rough,
Your body will be ſmooth, your Cheeks be ſoft,
Your eyes be ſparkling, and your lips be tempting:
And more perhaps might make me mad with love.
Ho! call a Parſon!

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Now my Lord?

sp.speaker: VVar.
sp.l: Ay! now.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: What, and my Husband dyed ſo very lately?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What then? what has the dead to do with us?

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: I'll rather go a begging with my Children.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Come leave this fooling!—by this kiſs you ſhall.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: I'll dye e're ſuffer all this barb'rous rudeneſs.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: VVell thou art a moſt beauteous Creature,
I'm going now Embaſſadour for France,
I'll let thee keep thy humour one month more
But then at my return be ſure I find thee
Divorc'd from ſorrow and the dead for ever;
Give not one ſigh or to the dead or living.
Sigh thou for any Man alive but me
And though a King he had better be a ſlave,
Sigh for the dead, I'll tear him from his Grave.—

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: What ſhall I do? for I abhor this man.
What comes into my thoughts? is it not ſaid
King Edward (for we now muſt call him ſo)
Lodges to night at his own Neighb'ring Caſtle?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: I'm inform'd he is a Prince
Of a moſt noble Nature; I'm reſolv'd
To fling my ſelf in ſorrow at his Feet,
And beg him to have pity on my Children,
What e're their Father was, they are not his Enemies;
And if I can obtain their Father's Lands,
Then I ſhall 'ſcape this man, I ſo much hate.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: The Scituation of this Caſtle pleaſes me.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: But, Sir, not me, for I'm afraid it ſtands
Too near a Beauty that once ſtopt your way,
And I'm afraid will do it once again.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Women are moving Creatures, and may follow us.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Pardon my confidence, I love to ſerve
My Friends as boldly as I fight my Enemies.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: You ſay well, Brother, and I'll promiſe you,
Nothing ſhall ſtay me here, beyond this night.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: A Lady, Sir, deſires to kiſs your hands.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A Lady? Poxo' Ladies; he is tinder
To every Lady, and will catch new fire.

div.stage: Enter Lady Grey, and her Women: She kneels, kiſſes King Edward's hand, he raiſes her, and Salutes her.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: A very lovely woman! he is ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I ne're had Eyes, or my eyes ne're ſaw beauty,
Till this amazing minute.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: So! he's gone:
Any one may have London now that will.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Sir, I preſent you humbly the petition
Of a poor Widow, and her little Orphans:
I am the Widow of one Sir John Grey,
Who in S. Alban's Battel loſt his life,
In the defence of him we thought our King.
If my poor Husband's Loyalty did err,
He dearly for that fatal error paid.
My humble prayer is, that my poor Orphans
May not be puniſh'd for their Fathers Faults,
If erring Loyalty can be a fault.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I am ſo rapt, I mind not what ſhe ſay;
Nor that ſhe is all this while upon her knees:
Pray, Madam, riſe,—leave us—.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: So ſhe (I find)
Muſt grant a thing, before her thing be granted.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Had you a Husband, Madam, did you ſay?

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, I had one at S. Alban's Battel;
His Name was Sir John Grey.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh happy man!
What excellence had he above mankind,
That he ſhou'd be more bleſt than all mankind?
And have you Children?

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Many poor young Orphans.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh! wondrous happy man t' enjoy this Woman!
I muſt inquire about her, I was never,
Never ſo charm'd before. My Lord, come hither,
Pray do you know this Lady?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, well.
She is the Widow of Sir John Grey of Grooby,
A man of Quality, and great Eſtate.
But a moſt vehement Lancaſtrian.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: No matter: of what Family is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Her quality does far exceed her Husbands;
And yet her Virtue does exceed her quality.
She is the Daughter of Sir Richard Woodvile,
Her Mother was ſometimes Dutcheſſe of Bedford.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Dutcheſſe of Bedford? Ha!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Dutcheſſe of Bedford.
And Daughter of the Earl of S. Pool.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Of noble birth, and by her Mothers ſide
Related to the houſe of Lancaſter.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: She is by Marriage, Sir; that was the cauſe
That Sir John Grey was ſuch a ſierce Lancaſtrian.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: She has Beauty, ſhe has Virtue, ſhe has Birth:
Why may not this fair Lady be a Queen?
But ſhe's a Subject, England will not like it.
And th' Engliſh Nation, like the Sea it governs,
Is bold and turbulent, and eaſily mov'd,
And always beats againſt the ſhore, that bounds it.
What? is the people free, and not the King?
Not free where every Slave is free, his bed?
Yes, ſo it is, it ſeems, and Engliſh fury
Will eaſily with any wind be rais'd,
To daſh the Palaces, and Beds of Kings.
Come what come will, this Lady ſhall be mine.
She ſhall be, or my Miſtreſs, or my Wife.
What was it, Madam, you deſir'd o' me?

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: To give poor Orphans, Sir, their Father's Lands.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Heaven forbid I ſhou'd retain 'em from 'em!

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Then, Sir, with humble thanks I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Hold, Madam, for I muſt have one word more,
I muſt impoſe a Tax upon this Land.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: It ſhall be thankfully, and gladly paid.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: It will I'm ſure more gladly be receiv'd.
It is an eaſie Tax, no more but Love.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: No Loyal Subjects, Sir, but love their King.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: But this is love, that none but you can grant.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: I do not underſtand your meaning, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Truly, I ſcarcely underſtand my ſelf,
For I have gaz'd my ſelf out of my Reaſon.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: With your permiſſion, Sir, I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh! you ſhall never, never part from me.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: VVhat do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I mean all the Love,
E're was or can be in the heart of man.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Love, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Ay Love.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: I dare not underſtand you,
Becauſe I dare not think ill of my Prince.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Can there be ill in Love? there will be all
The happineſs to me, glory to you,
Your heart and mine can poſſibly deſire.
Why do you tremble, and draw back your hand?
You muſt not, ſhall not ſtir till you have granted,
What all this languiſhing, and preſſing means.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Oh! I ſhall ſwoon! wou'd I had ne're come here!
Sir, I thus low moſt humbly beg of you,
Let it ſuffice your conquering armes have ſeiz'd
My Husbands life, your laws have ſeiz'd his Lands,
Seek not to take my honour, and my Vertue.
I never fought againſt you, ne're oppos'd you.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I wrong her beauty, it deſerves a Crown,
Every look claims a Kingdom as it's due;
And I, who gain'd my right, ſhou'd not wrong others.
Madam, I mean nothing but honour to you,
I am reſolv'd to make you Queen of England.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Now, Sir, you mean diſhonour to your ſelf.
I am as much unworthy to be Queen,
As I'm above ſerving an ill deſign.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Rather the crown's unworthy of your Beauty.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: It is impoſſible, you ſhou'd deſcend
To ſuch mean thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: It is impoſſible,
I ſhou'd have happineſs without your Love.
I had rather with your Love be your dead Husband,
Than with your hatred be a living King.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: I lately wiſh'd I never had come here
For my own ſake, I wiſh it now for yours:
Oh! think Sir, what will all your Subjects ſay?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: They'l ſay, I am in Love.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: But will they not
Be much diſpleas'd, their Prince ſhou'd love ſo low?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I give them leave to chuſe where they like beſt;
Why ſhou'd I be the only man impos'd on?

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: But I'm a Widow, and have many Children.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: And I have Children too, though I'm a Batchelour;
So we are tryed, and ſhall be ſure of Heirs.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: But you have ſent to Court a foreign Princeſſe,
May bring your Kingdom great advantages.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Then let my Kingdom go and marry her.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Conſider, you may enrage the Earl of Warwick.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: He is my Friend, and Servant, not my Guardian.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: But, Sir, they ſay you are promis'd to another.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: When I'm a prieſt I will do penance for it.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: I am afraid you'l loſe your Subjects love.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Why ſhou'd I loſe their love, by loving Subjects?

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: But you have many Subjects of more Beauty.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: My Subjects if they pleaſe may marry 'em.
I give them freedom, and I'll take my own,
I'll take it too this minute.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: At firſt ſight?
You'l think me, Sir, immodeſt, ſhou'd I grant.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: A King is above forms; I'll have it ſo.
Then come away.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: What in this Mourning habit?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I marry not your habit, but your ſelf.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: The world will much condemn you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I care not,
I had rather live a minute in your Armes,
Than many ages in the praiſe of Fools.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Moſt happy tydings, Sir! Henry your Enemy,
Wandring alone, diſguis'd in homely habit,
Was taken by the Keepers of the Forreſt,
As he was reading in ſhady Covert.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Good news indeed! where is he? bring him to me.
sp.stage: Enter King Henry in a poor habit, brought in by a Couple of Forreſters.
sp.l: Why how now Henry? in this humble dreſs?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Inſult not, Edward, over my misfortunes,
But from this garb, in which thou ſcarce canſt know me,
Learn thou to know thy ſelf; for in my fall
Heaven humbles every King as well as me.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Henry, I pity thee, thou doſt not ſuffer
For thy own Crimes, but thoſe of thy uſurping
And trayterous Anceſtours. To London with him.
And keep him a cloſe Priſoner in the Tower.
But let him there command all things but Liberty.
How all my happineſſes flow together:
A Crown upon my Head, my chiefeſt Enemy
Under my Feet, and Beauty in my Armes.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What's this? a Chaplain call'd for? he is mad—
He'll marry her, and marry at firſt ſight.
Marry a Subject, nay, and a mean Subject,
Nay, the poor wretched leavings of a Subject,
A Widow, and the Widow of a Knight!
I fear this Marriage will enrage the Kingdom,
But I fear more the furious Warwick's Rage,
Whoſe haughty temper will not hear the affront
Of being ſent on a mock-Embaſſy.
Now, though I'd have him fight him, have him kill him,
Kill both my Brothers, if he'd ſet up me:
But that he cannot do, for he muſt fight
In Henry's Name, and ſo muſt ſet up Henry.
He's not far from hence, I'll after him,
And for my own ſake I will pacify him;
And let the King mean while finiſh his marriage.
For I wou'd have him finiſh it, becauſe
I'm told he has another Wife, if ſo,
The Children of this Marriage muſt be Baſtards,
Then when I've kill'd Henry, and his Son,
And by ſome Arts deſtroy'd my Brother Clarence,
The King once dead, I'll Baſtardize his Children;
Then am I King, but ſome will ſay by Villany:
That's Villany, that by it's ill ſucceſs
Betray's a man and into ruin throws;
When once it gains a Crown, it vertue grows.

div.stage: The Scene a Chapel Edward, and Lady Grey, A Prieſt, Attendants. The ſolemnity ended. Enter Lady Elianor Butler.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Ha! is it ſo? and can the news be true?
It cannot be, I'll not believe my Eyes,
I'll know the truth—King Edward.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Lady Elianor?—

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: My heart's ſo full I cannot ſpeak to him.
Ha! is he ſhunning me? Nay, then he's guilty.
What is the cauſe, King Edward, you wou'd ſhun me?
Am I ſo ſtrangely chang'd ſince I laſt ſaw you,
You cannot bear my ſight?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: No ſurely, Madam,
You are not alter'd for the worſe, I'm certain,
And for the better 'tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Oh! Sir, your paſſion's dead, and you are weaving
Garlands of fine expreſſions for it's Funeral.
If my ſmall beauty were extreamly improv'd,
I were a horrid ſight to thee; an Angel
Is a moſt dreadful Viſion to a ſinner.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Who is this?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: One your beauty Triumphs over.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Come to the Bar, and anſwer me, great ſinner,
What doſt thou with this wretched Woman here?
How far haſt thou undone thy Soul and her?
I'm told, thou haſt ſinn'd with her even to Marriage.
Thou durſt not do it ſure!—ſay, is it true?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Madam, I muſt confeſs, 'tis very true.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: How? is it true?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Yes, Madam, it is true.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: What after all the Oaths thou haſt ſworn to me?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Beauties, like palaces, have ſeveral ways
Of acceſs to' em; I believ'd thoſe Oaths
A form of ſpeaking, which did pleaſe you beſt.
What form o' damning in do you expect?
The loweſt place in Hell?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Rather a place
Among the Saints of the Old Teſtament.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Yes, Jewiſh Saints; but pray, will Chriſtian Saintſhip
Admit ſuch things?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh! yes! I, when I pleaſe,
Can have a diſpenſation from his Holineſs.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: What then his Holineſs will be your pardon?
A very excellent office for a Pope!
To be the Univerſal Bawd of Chriſtendom!
A very excellent Shepherd, that will give
His ſheep a diſpensation to be rotten!

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Well, you ſhall be my fair Confeſſor then,
I'll own my ſins to you, and ask your pardon.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: And doſt thou hope to have it?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I will give you
Any other ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: What? thy blood?
Do, kill thy ſelf I ſwear I'll pardon thee.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I wou'd do much for that; but I wou'd live
A little while to mend and to repent.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Would'ſt thou repent? Oh! I will pray thou mayſt.
Oh may heaven laſh thee with ſo many plagues,
May fill thee, and ſurround thee with repentance!
I will not curſe this moſt unhappy VVoman;
For ſhe alas! is curſt enough in thee.
Poor VVoman, he has gull'd thee horridly,
For he has only pick'd the name of wife
Out of my Marriage ſheet's, to hide thy ſhame with.
As for his love in which thou think'ſt thee happy,
'Tis like a Green-land-Summer, ſhort and hot,
And whilſt it laſts 'tis day, all ſmiling day,
But ſoon he goes to viſit other provinces,
But oh! he never like the Sun returns.
Farewel, poor wretch, pitied not envied by me,
Thou think'ſt we part with very different fortunes,
I go to ſorrow, and thou ſtay'ſt with joy;
Alas! I leave thee but in a fools paradiſe,
And very ſhortly we ſhall meet in Bedlam.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Oh, Sir, I like not this! this is an ill
Beginning o' this day.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: VVhy ſo, my Love?
That's well begun, that is begun with ſacrifice,
She is thy ſacrifice.

div.stage: ACry within, Arm, Arm. Treaſon, VVarwick! VVarwick! Then Enter Warwick and his Souldiers, and ſeize Edward, and Lady Grey.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Why how now Warwick? What doſt mean by this?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What mean'ſt thou Duke to put this ſcorn upon me?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Duke! when we parted thou didſt call me King.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then I diſgrac'd the Title, and I gave it
To one, who merit's not the name of Friend.
Were I a King, I'd hang that common Fellow,
That ſhou'd abuſe a Friend, as thou haſt me,
And ſuch a friend as I have been to thee.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Thou doſt abuſe thy ſelf, in talking thus.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then it is no abuſe to me, to make me
The ſeorn of every French Page, and waiting Woman.
The Marriage is agreed on, nothing wanting
To compleat all, but my arrival there,
And all my Equipage and Train are gone.
Now, when inſtead of me, this news arrives,
I ſhall have all my Servants hiſt from France,
My ſelf be made a Common publick jeſt,
I ſhall be call'd the great Ambaſſador,
That goe's with ſplendour to negotiate nothing.
But my Embaſſage is but like my conqueſt,
For I have fought for thee, that is, for nothing.
I've ſtole the Royal Robes to adorn nothing,
And help it to another nothing—Woman.

sp.speaker: La. Gr.
sp.l: Pll tell you, Sir, whence all this fury ſpring's;
This haughty Lord, who thinks his Sword has given
Chains to our Sex, as well as to the men,
Did ſtrive to drag me to his marriage bed.
And uſing many threats, I out of fear,
Made ſome faint yieldings, but he finding now
I'm plac'd above his reach, his burning envy
Seek's to deſtroy what he cannot attain;
Then calls his fury his revenge of honour.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Is that the myſtery indeed?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Yes, Duke;
Thou with a Crown haſt bought a Widow from me;
And bought her with the Kingdom which I gave thee.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Com'ſt thou to ruin me for love of beauty,
And thou thy ſelf rebel for love of it?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I come to puniſh thy ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I did not know thy Love, but ſay I did,
If I commit a fault to take a Woman,
To whom thou haſt no right, then what doſt thou,
Who plunder'ſt thy Kings Right, thy Countreys peace?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Thy glory's mine, my Sword created it.
My Crime is thine, thy wrongs to me created it.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I'm a great Criminal to wrong a Subject,
Thou none, to ruin both the King and Kingdom.
Thus men, like Bears, devour the young of others;
But ſtrive to lick their own fowl Cubs to ſhape.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I do no wrong in ruining you all,
I but reſtore to every thing it's own.
I to the Kingdom ſhall reſtore the damn'd
Confuſion, which my Sword took away from it.
I ſhall reſtore this Woman to her tears.
I found her weeping over her dead Husband:
I'll leave her weeping over thy dead fortunes.
I will reſtore thee, and all thy Family
To the ſubjection from which I advanc'd it.
Thy fortunes to their proper ſtate I'll bring,
Beauty ſhallbe thy plague, thy foe thy King.

div.head: ACT. V.
Scene London.
div.stage: Enter King Henry in a rich Robe, under a Canopy: The Queen and Prince followed by Warwick, and Guards, with their Swords drawn. Shouts, and Acclamations. They paſs over the Stage. The Scene changes to the Palace. Enter King Henry, Queen, Prince, Warwick,

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: NOw, Sir, you are King again, this valiant Lord
Has left the horrid deſarts of Rebellion;
Where he, and all his glorious deeds were loſt,
And found the Road of Honour.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I confeſs,
Fortune did miſlead me, and I the Kingdom,
To give your Royal Rights to a falſe Prince,
Who has the Royal bloud, no Royal Vertues;
So has no right to Crowns thoſe vertues gain'd.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I give you thanks, my Lord, for your great gifts;
Life, Freedom, and a Crown; I call 'em gifts,
'Cauſe you can take 'em from me, or let me keep 'em.
To Life, and Freedom, I have a clear Title;
Becauſe I ne're did any ill, to forfeit 'em.
But oh! I am afraid to wear the Crown
For fear I ſhare the murder that procur'd it.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Oh! Spiritleſs Prince! born for a Chain, a Priſon:
What if your Grandfather murder'd his King?
Muſt you take Phyſick for his ſickneſſes?
Nay, muſt you dye? for a Kings Crown and Life
Go both together; So King Richard found it.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Sir, all our lives wholly depend on yours.
And for one fault of my dead Grandfather,
Which he perhaps repented, will you puniſh
Thouſands? You will ſin to loſe a Crown,
More than my Grandfather did do to gain one.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: If you will doom your ſelf to be depos'd,
Becauſe the Crown was gotten by ill means;
By the ſame law
You may hang half your Kingdom:
If men by inheriting their Fathers Fortunes,
Inherit the Crimes, by which their Fathers gain'd 'em,
Where is the Nation wou'd not deſerve hanging?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Sir, talk no more; you are, and ſhall be King.
All power is from Heav'n, Earth, or Hell.
Heav'n ſend's you his conſent in my ſuceſs,
The People ſend you all their votes in me;

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: My Lord, I have a Conſcience I'll not part with
For this and many Kingdoms; but you tell me,
That Royal Virtue firſt gave royal Power;
Now I have Royal Virtue, Edward none;
And therefore I muſt Reign, and he be ruin'd.
Oh! my Lord, this is a confounding principle.
If Kings may loſe their Rights for want of Virtue,
And Subjects are the Judges of that Virtue;
Then Kings are Subjects, and all Subjects Kings:
And by that Law that Subjects may deſtroy
Their Kings for want of Virtue, other Subjects
May think thoſe Subjects Rogues, and cut their throats.
Thus Babel might be builded, but no Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Sir, if you be no King, we are all Rebels,
And ought to dye.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And you ſhall reign or dye;
If you refuſe the Crown, I'll carry it back;
And with it both your heads, to ranſommine.
I'll quench your lives, as Mariners wou'd do
Falſe lights, that lead their Veſſels to deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Why do you pauſe, Sir, will you rather dye,
And let your Son dye too, e're be a King?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Powerful Nature is too hard for me.
Will it not coſt more bloud, if I ſhou'd Reign?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: The VVar is at an end, Edward's my Pris'ner;
Not only doom'd by Heaven unfit to Reign;
But by his fleſh and bloud, his Brother Clarence,
VVho has revolted from him, and brought all
His Troops to mine, and to create between us
A laſting league, marries my youngeſt Daughter.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: And I have given my heart, Sir, to her ſiſter.
Oh! do not make me wretched every way.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Oh! Nature conquer's me!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Oh! happy conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Upon my knees, Sir, I return you thanks.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: See, here come's he, who gallantly to ſerve
His King and Country will forſake his Brother.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I thought my blood derived a Crown to us,
But now I find it derives only Treaſon,
To clear the taint, I come to ſet it boyling
Over a flaming zeal for the Kings ſervice.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: VVhat think you now, Sir? do you judge your title
Good, when your very Enemies proclaim it?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I find it's Heav'ns will, that I ſhou'd Reign.
My noble Friends, let me embrace you both.
My Lord of Warwick you are fortunate,
I muſt beg you to rule, for I'm afraid,
My thwarting Stars will blaſt this bleſſed Land.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Your Majeſty is wiſe, to foreſee evils,
And good, that you wou'd ſave your people from 'em.
Here ſtands a Prince moſt worthy of command.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: The world has not more worth, than th' Earl of Warwick.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Give me your hands, I joyn you both together.
I make you both Protectors of the Kingdom,
Rule you, while I wait only on devotion.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: So, now, my Son, thy inheritance is ſafe.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: May I be happy in my Miſtreſs too?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes, if the King conſent.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: The Marriages ſhall then be both this minute.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: VVith whom is Edward truſted?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: With my Brother,
The Arch-biſhop of York.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I'm told he gives him liberty
To hunt; and let's him go out ſlender guarded.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I will have that reform'd; in the mean while,
We openly will proclaim Edward a Traytour,
And ſeize his Lands.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Let's guard this City well;
He has friends here, chiefly among the Women;
And they rule men.

div.stage: Scene London. Enter Edward, Richard, diſguis'd.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Uſurping Henry, and falſe changing Warwick
Little think certain ruin is ſo near 'em.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I cannot tell what abſolution
The Prieſt of York may give his Brother Warwick,
For all his horrid perjury's and Treaſon's,
Warwick will give him none for your eſcape.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I ſhou'd be ſorry if hoſt, th' Arch-biſhop,
For all his civil entertainment of me,
Shou'd have his reck'ning paid him with an Ax.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: So ſhou'd I too, for if inſtead of giving you
The publick Freedom, which you had to hunt;
He had confin'd you to Domitians chace,
Only to hunt flyes in a bed chamber,
You had not now been here to hunt his Brother.
Well, Sir, Go you to all your City Friends,
I'll to the Court; I have intelligence,
How I may eaſily ſurprize your Enemies,
If it be feazible, I'll venture on it.—

div.stage: Prince, George, their Brides, and a Prieſt at the Altar; near 'em King Henry, Queen, Warwick, Guards, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Arm! Arm! Arm! Lord Edward's in the City.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Thou art mad.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: I wiſh I were. I ſay, Lord Edward
Is in the City.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: In the Womens hearts?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: No, in the head of Troops of men and Women.
There's nothing that can get a Pike or Spit,
But cry they'l live and dye by brave King Edward.
Richard is with him; they are all marching hither.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Oh! good Arch-biſhop,
You are a faithful Brother,
We are very wiſe to truſt our ſouls with prieſts,
When their own Brothers cannot truſt their heads with 'em▪
I know this Trayt'rous Prieſt has ſold my head
To Edward, for th' Archbiſhoprick of Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Do not too raſhly cenſure an Archbiſhop.
Edward might 'ſcape by wiles.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How? cheat a Prieſt?
Then he deſerves the Kingdom for his cunning.
Do you think it is eaſie to cheat prieſts,
Who by the help, but of ſome barbarous words;
As, Entity, Vnity, Verity, Bonity,
Qniddity, Quantity, Quality Cauſality,
Have conjur'd all you Kings out of their Kingdoms?
And Edward cheat a Prieſt,
Who let a VVidow cheat him of his Kingdom?
Oh! but you'll ſay, a VVoman cheated Adam.
But Prieſts cheat women, cheat 'em too of things
Dear to 'em as their lives, their bawdy ſecrets.
They make S. Peter's Keys
Open all Italian locks—enough of prating.
I'll go beat Edward, and then hang my Brother.
My Lord,
Draw up your Troops; you, Sir, ſtay here:
You are unfortunate,
I do not care,
To have your curs'd Stars among my men.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I'll follow, and do you, Son, leave your Bride,
And go with us, for I'm reſolv'd to ſee thee
Heir to the Crown, or dying at my Feet.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Fear nothing, Love, I ſhall return victorious
Your Royal bleſſing!—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: VVhat ſad divining thoughts are theſe within me?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Oh Sir, why do you weep?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: For thee, my Son,
I'm bound in duty to thy ſoul to tell thee,
Something from Heaven ſuggeſts our deaths are near.
Thou firſt muſt dye, I muſt behold the loſs
Of all that's dear to me, and then muſt dye.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Oh Sir!—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo! we never in this world
Muſt meet again.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Oh how ſhall I be able
To fight, when e're I ſee the enemy,
My King and Father wounds me to the heart?
See, my Love's weeping too, I'm ſhot o' both ſides;
And in my heart the deadly Arrows meet:
I'll rather run among the Enemies Swords,
Than here be kill'd with ſorrow by my Friends.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: So, now will I go joyn my Brother Edward:
I am ſecure of Warwick's beautious daughter.
Now let the Devil take Warwick and his Treaſon,
He made me take that braſs Coin with his Daughter;
But I will pay him the damn'd portion back again.
He made me ſwear he'll ſay, but war's a game,
And ſo is Love, and Gameſters Oaths are nothing.
My Brothers Souldiers are got in the place,
They ſeek their Enemies, but ſhall find Friends.

div.stage: Enter Richard, George, Souldiers, and ſeize Henry and the Women.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: How now! thou Traytour! thou unnatural Traytor!

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Thou wrong'ſt me, I am as Loyal as thy ſelf.
VVhat I have done, was only in deſign
To gain this beauty, and now ſhe is mine
My Loyalty is mine.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Can this be true?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Thou ſaw'ſt it true, thou ſaw'ſt I fought for thee.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Thou didſt; but I believ'd it was thy Cowardize,
That made thee now betray thy Friend, as luſt
Made thee betray thy Brother.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: It is falſe.
And if I don't appear to day in Battel,
As valiant, and as Loyal as thy ſelf,
I'll kill my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Do that, and I'll embrace thee.
But let's away: our Royal Brother wants us.—

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Oh! curſed Traytour! why wou'd you e're truſt
One that was always falſe?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I was bewitch'd,
To truſt a man, who had betray'd his Brother.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: My Fathers words now ſink into my breaſt;
He ſaid at parting, we ſhou'd never meet
On Earth again.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: VVell if the Villains murder him,
I will revenge his bloud, and make you King.
VVhene're I went to work to make a King,
Ine're yet fail'd, whatever ſtuff I had;
But hark the Traytors come! let us fall on.

div.stage: An Alarm. Enter Edward, Enter Lady Elianor in mans habit.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Turn this way, Edward; here's an Enemy,
Thirſts for thy bloud.

div.stage: [La. El. and Ed. Fight, La. El. falls.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: VVhat bold young man is this?
Thou art diſpatch'd, I wonder who thou art.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Look on me well—ſee if thou doſt not know me.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: May I believe my eyes!

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Thou may'ſt, King Edward,
They ſpeak more truth, than e're thou didſt to me.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh! killing ſight!

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: VVou'd thou hadſt never ſeen me,
The cold Earth had not been my Death-bed then,
Nor had I needed (as I do) two graves,
One for my ſelf, the other for my name.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh Heaven!
How have I wrong'd this beautious Creature!
Firſt robb'd her of her Fame, now of her Life!

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Ah! Monarch, do I merit this for Love?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Oh no, but I deſerve a thouſand plagues;
And I have here with my own hand broke open
A fair Pandora's box to let 'em out,
To fly about my head.

sp.speaker: La. El.
sp.l: Indeed, King Edward,
My injuries have already found thee out,
Have driven thee from thy throne, how far will drive thee,
I cannot tell, I will not curſe thee now:
Curſing is not a language ſpoke in Heaven,
And I am very near that glorious Kingdom,
Therefore I'll ſpeak the language that is bleſſing.
May this be the laſt day of all thy Troubles!
And I be the laſt woman thou ſhalt wrong!
May Heaven forgive thy broken Vows, as I do,
And quicklier forget 'em all than thou didſt!
And this one poor requeſt I beg of thee:
Since I was all the ſtaine of my great Family,
And I have made thy ſelf, who wert the cauſe of it,
With thy own Sword, cut out the ruined piece,
Oh hide it, where it may no more be ſeen,
But be forgot by all as 'twill by thee!

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: She's gone! She's gone!
Oh! thou ſweet injur'd beauty,
I never ſhall forget thee whilſt I live,
Thy wrongs I fear will haunt my mind and fortune,
In this ſweet ſpot of Earth I fear I've planted
Much miſchief for my ſelf; I gather'd all
The Sweets, and now Thorns will ſpring up to tear me.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Oh Sir, the Earl of Warwick ranges o're
The Field, with ſo much fury, and ſucceſs
Your Troops are juſt upon the point of flying.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: My puniſhment ſo ſoon purſue my Crime!
This beauties wrongs ſteel that proud Rebels Sword,
And give it all the kneenneſs that it has.
Oh Heav'n hide thy eyes from this ſweet Creature,
At leaſt for this one hour; and here I vow,
I will give o're robbing ſuch ſpicy Iſles,
And take an honeſt dwelling at my own,
Leſt ſailing to a fro a Tempeſt fall,
That ſhall revenge the injuries of 'em all.

div.stage: Enter Edward and VVarwick Fighting, VVar. falls.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Now I am King of England, and Iowe,
My Crown to my own Sword, and not to thine.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Inſult not, Edward, for I am not kill'd
By thee, but Henries curſed Deſtiny.
I'm cruſh'd under the wheels of his damn'd fortune,
I am ground all to pieces by his Stars.
My fortune ſickned when I firſt came under 'em;
Truth is, my Spirit led her ſuch a dance,
She cou'd not keep me company, but tyr'd,
Now ſit's her down, and like a poor caſt Whore,
Is glad to be pick'd up by any body.
Now thou maiſt baniſh fear, for I am dying;
Who, when I liv'd, cou'd frown thee into a Subject,
Bury thee in the wrinckle of my brow.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Talk not of burying Kings, but rather think
Of burying all thy Crimes in penitence.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: My greateſt Crime is, that I e're ſerv'd thee,
Whoſe baſe ingratitude has ruin'd me;
I gave thee Kingdoms, and thou giv'ſt me death.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I ne're wrong'd thee, nor didſt thou e're ſerve me,
Thou haſt been wrong'd by nothing, but my ignorance,
And haſt ſerv'd nothing, but thy vanity;
And nothing elſe I fear will e're reward thee.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Now, Sir, I hope you will forgive my errours
For Beauties ſake, for Beauty drew me in,
And you have felt the mighty power of Beauty.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Brother, your errours are all buried under
Heaps of my Enemies, you have kill'd to day.
I have diſpatch'd my greateſt Enemy;
Warwick will make, and unmake no more Kings.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: And the bold Amazon Queen, and inſolent Boy,
Her fierce Son Edward, are both taken Priſoners.
I've order'd, Sir, they ſhall attend you here.
And here they are.

div.stage: Enter Queen, Prince, Guarded as Priſoners.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: So, Madam!—and young Edward,
What ſatisfaction will you make to me,
For all the Miſchief you have done my Kingdom,
And all the Trouble you have given me?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: What ſatisfaction wilt thou make my Father,
Me, and the Kingdom, for thy bold uſurping
My Fathers Crown, and my inheritance,
Ruining us, and ſlaughtering our people?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Oh! that thy Father had been ſo reſolv'd!

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: That ſo your Diſtaff might have been our Scepter.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Why, how now AEſop? Nay, miſtake me not,
AEſop I mean in Body not in mind.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Brat!—I will cruſh thy brains out.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Hold, forbear—
He is a Boy.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why, then to School with him,
To learn him manners.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: If I learn thy manners,
The Devil muſt be my Tutour.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Hold your peace,
You fooliſh Child.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: The Boy's too malapert.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: The man is too perjur'd, I mean perjur'd George,
And you are all Traytors to me your Prince.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: How now, proud Boy? take that.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Nay, then take that—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: And that for twitting me with Perjury.

div.stage: [Rich. and Geo. draw, and kill him.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Oh! they have kill'd my Son—oh murderers!
Oh! kill me too.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Marry with all my heart!

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Hold, Brother, we have done too much already.
Why wou'd you cruelly kill the poor Boy?
I ſtruck him in my Choler, but I meant him
No farther harm.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Who cou'd forbear?—beſides,
Shou'd we have let him live to cut our Throats?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: What wou'd have grown up with him but Rebelion?
Why ſhou'd a Sprig grow up to be a Tree,
That wou'd breed nothing elſe but Caterpillars?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: His Mother Swoon's, uſe means for her recovery.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Oh, my dear Son is kill'd! my Son is kill'd!
Speak to thy Mother, Son! can'ſt thou not ſpeak?
Oh murd'rers, Butchers, Traytors, Cannibals,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Hence with this rayling Woman.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ay hence with me,
Out of the world; I prithee, Richard, kill me:
Murder is all the Almes thou giveſt the miſerable;
Beſtow thy bloudy Charity upon me;
Have pity on a Queen that begs it of thee.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: We pity not thoſe that are born to beggery;
If thou doſt beg, 'tis but thy native poverty.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Inſult not o're a miſerable Woman;
Madam, I pray go hence, you ſhall be us'd
With all reſpect.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: All the reſpect of Murderers
Is death; Oh! bloudy George do thou beſtow it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I ſwear I will not do thee ſo much kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ay, but thou uſeſt to for ſwear thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Madam, pray go—

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Oh! Edward, Richard, George,
Be it to you, and yours, as to this Prince,
For 'twere a ſhame the Sons of Executioners
Shou'd e're be Kings.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Away, with her!—away with her.
sp.stage: [The Guard lead out the Qu. and carry out the Pr.
sp.l: Now I will to the Tower to diſpatch Henry,
Till he be kill'd our work is done by halves.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Sir, If you pleaſe, I'll viſit my young Bride.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I have a Beautious Bride to viſit too—

div.stage: Scene, a Room in the Tower, Henry Sleeping. Enter the Ghoſt of Richard the Second.

sp.speaker: Gh.
sp.l: Wake, Henry, wake to weep, then ſleep for ever;
Thy Kingdom's gone, thy only ſon is kill'd,
A Dagger is preparing for thy Boſom;
And when thy bloud is ſhed, my bloud will ſleep.
I'm that King Richard, whom thy Grandfather
Depos'd, and murder'd; and both long and loud
My bloud for vengeance call'd, and vengeance had,
Firſt in the wounded Conſcience of thy Grandfather,
Whom all the Royal Oyntment cou'd not heal.
He liv'd in trouble, and he dy'd with horror.
And next on the ſhort life of thy great Father;
Who liv'd no longer than to beget thee,
Who haſt loſt all the glories of thy Father,
And doſt inherit nothing but the curſes,
Due to thy Grand-father; nor doe's the ſtorm
Of vengeance only fall on the Uſurpers,
But on the Souls, and miſerable Race
Of all the Traytors, and the Fools, that Flatter'd
Thy Grandfather's ſucceſsful Villany;
Who did not know, Kings cannot dye alone.
And now their names are rotting, Children dying,
Their Houſes burnt on Earth, their Souls in Hell.
Grin at your Grandfathers, you dying wretches
Cover'd all o're with ſhame, and duſt, and bloud:
For this Eſtate their Villany conveigh'd you,
Th' aſcending dirty Vapours of the Earth
Breed all the ſtorms ith' Ayr. When e're Oh! England,
Thou haſt a mind to ſee thy Cities fir'd,
Thy people ſlaughter'd, and thy Country deſolate,
Send-all the dirty Traytours in the Kingdom
To climb the Royal Rights, and Throne invade,
Then a high road for vaſt deſtruction's made.

div.stage: The Ghoſt goes out, and enters with ſoft Muſick one clad in a white Robe.

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: Let not this frightful Viſion, pious Henry,
Diſturb thy gentle Soul; it is not rais'd,
To breed a ſtorm, now thou art near thy Haven;
Rather to calm the Tempeſt in thy mind,
By pointing to thee, on what diſmal Rock
Thy Kingdom, and thy life are caſt away,
The bloudy uſurpation of thy Grandfather.
The Crown of England is not made of Clay
The Common people, ſo can ne're be crumbled
Into that dirt, 'tis not compos'd if it:
Nor made of Iron, the Sword, ſo cannot ruſt;
But of unmingled ſolid laſting Gold,
Of Antient Rights, and 'tis the gift of Heav'n,
Therefore to Heaven only can be forfeited,
Therefore 'tis call'd Imperial and Sacred,
And therefore carefully rail'd in by Laws;
And torn will be his ſacrilegious hand,
Who has no Right to it, and yet dares reach it,
And dares preſumptuouſly pretend a Right,
Becauſe he ſtands upon the peoples heads,
Such was the bold Ambition of thy Grandfather,
And heav'n frowns upon his Sins, not thee:
Then do not think thy ſelf unkindly us'd,
Religious Henry, that Heaven takes away,
What is not thine; all that is truly thine
Thou ſhalt not part with, but for great advantages,
Thy Son is taken from thee here, to live with thee
Above for ever; thou ſhalt loſe thy life,
Only to exchange it for Eternity;
Loſe humble quiet, for exalted Joy;
A taſte of which wafted in Heavenly Harmony,
Pure as this lower droſſy air admits,
I bring thee down to raiſe thy Spirits high.

div.head: A SONG
div.stage: Sung by Spirits to King Henry as he lies aſleep.

lg.l: Can be on Earth, a Ruin'd King.
As all the Joyes on Earth Vnite,
To make his proſp'rous Fortune bright;
So every woe, to ſhade his Night.
He has but one poor Joy, the Grave,
A thing that's free to every Slave,
And that with eaſe he cannot have.
For Daggers, Swords, and Poyſon lye
To guard his Tomb, and make him buy
With pain the wretched eaſe to dye.
But comfort, Prince, thy death is near,
For Dead thou haſt no more to fear,
A fallen Monarchs Hell is here.
To Fortune he can nothing owe,
For all that e're ſhe did beſtow,
He payes again in heavy woe.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: What have I ſeen and heard?—Oh! come my murderers,
And ſet me forwards on my way to Heaven,
Whilſt I've ſuch rich proviſions for my journey.
Here comes my murderer, leſs horrid to me
In bringing Death, than bringing to my ſight
The horrid Author of my ſweet Son's death.
For ſo in dream it was reveal'd to me.
My bloudy Grandfather deſtroy'd King Richard,
And now a bloudy Richard deſtroys me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Go, leave us to our ſelves, we muſt confer.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: What bloudy Scene has Roſcius now to Act?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Do you ſuſpect me? fear haunt's guilty minds;
The Thief thinks every buſh an Officer.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The Bird that ſees the Buſh where once it ſelf
Was lim'd, and it's ſweet young lim'd caught and kill'd,
Cannot but hover round it with misdoubt.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What an aſpiring Fool was he of Creet,
VVho taught his Son the office of a Fowl?
And drown'd the Boy by teaching him to fly.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Indeed my Boy was Icarus, thy Brother
Edward the Sun that did diſſolve his wings,
And thou the gulph that ſwallowed up his life.
But many a thouſand wretched Father more,
And many an Orphans water-ſtanding-eye,
And many a Widows Groan, and old man's Sigh
Shall rue the Hour that ever thou waſt born.
When thou waſt born, nature by horrid ſignes
Gave notice to the world of coming Miſchief;
The Birds of night did ſhrieke and cry to tell,
That Hour there was a Child of darkneſs born.
Winds blew down Trees as hell were making gallowſes,
Thy mother had a kind of Helliſh pain
As She had been in labour of a Devil.
Thy legs came firſt, and thou wert born with Teeth,
And cam'ſt to bite—

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I'll hear no more—dye, Prophet,
For this (among the reſt) I was ordain'd!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I, and for much more ſlaughter after this.
Heaven forgive me my ſins, and thee this murder!

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Thou didſt ſay truth, I came with my legs forward
Into the World, but 'twas to o're take thee,
And all that ſtand between the Crown and me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What noiſe is that?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: The King is Coming, Sir,
And all the Court with him, to ſee the Priſoner,
And comfort him; the King intends to keep
His Court here till his Coronation.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay, then I muſt be gone, he will be angry
At what I've done—

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Where is your priſoner?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: He's murder'd.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Murder'd? Oh! thou bloudy Villain!
Durſt thou do this, when I commanded thee
To give him all Princely reſpect and uſage?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Sir, on my knees I do beſeech you hear me:
Your Brother, my Lord Richard, came to viſit him,
And was left with him by his own command,
And now he's fled; that none but he cou'd do this deed.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Sir, I believe him; this is like my Brother.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Heaven to his crooked ſhape has bent his ſoul.
He was deſign'd for miſchief, and thruſt forward
Unfiniſh'd in the World to loſe no time
And I believe if we don't watch him narrowly,
He'l make no ſcruple to uſe us as rudely,
For crowding rudely into the world before him;
But I believe I'm ſafe, England, by this time,
Has had enough of Rebels, and Uſurpers.
I faney now the Sons of thoſe poor Genlemen,
Thoſe honeſt fooliſh cheated Gentlemen,
Who did turn Rebels but they meant no harm,
Who fought their King, ſlaughter'd their Friends, and Kinſmen,
Deſtroy'd their Country, but they meant no harm,
And for reward had all their houſes burn'd,
Their Wives and Daughters raviſhed, their lands ſeiz'd,
And themſelves knock'd o'th' head, but meant no harm.
I ſay, I fancy their unhappy Off-ſpring
Will prove exceeding honeſt Loyal Subjects,
For by their Fathers Ruine they have learnt VVit.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: That's all a Nation gets by Civil War.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Yes, with the Prodigal they learn, 'tis better
Obeying their Kings, the Fathers of their Country,
Than run and waſt their Fortune and their Liberties,
And do the drudgeries of proud Uſurpers,
Who will perhaps ſet 'em to keep their Swine.
And after a long beggery and ſlavery
Return with ſhame and ſorrow to their Loyalty.
Take up the Body of that unfortunate Prince,
I will beſtow Royal interrement on it.
His, and the Kingdom's dreadful Ruines prove,
A Monarch's Right is an unſhaken Rock,
No ſtorms of War nor time can wear away,
And Wracks thoſe Pirates that come there for prey.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: TO a cloy'd lover, with his Miſtreſs tyr'd,
How pall'd ſhe ſeems, who once was ſo deſir'd?
He Shuns her ſight, and when ſhe comes to ſin,
Damn her, he cries, tell her I'm not within:
So nauſeous and unpleaſant now are grown
All the delights of wit to this cloyd Town.
Nowon Religious Brawls your time you ſpend;
When ſinners grow devout, they're near their end.
The Nation, of a natural humour Gay,
That in vile Pamphlets does begin to pray
The ayd of Raſcals for her ſickly State,
Is in a malady as deſperate
As the young Spark, who late Religion ſcorn'd,
Grown deadly ſick, is a Fanatick turn'd,
And begs, in bits o' Paper up and down,
The Prayers of all the Godly of the Town.
Oh! we are ſick, at leaſt our brains are bad,
England is ne're devout till it is mad.
Our Fathers to their coſt did find it ſo,
And ſmall things will make mad men fight, you know.
Oh! what a Bedlam once was this ſweet place,
When graceleſs Rogues did Fight about free-grace?
And wilful Fools wou'd obſtinately ſpill
His bloud, who durſt ſay man had a free-will?
Of all our Civil broyles, thoſe we have ſhewn
To day, our Nation with leaſt ſhame may own.
For Subjects then for loyalty did fight,
And Princes to maintain their Royal Right.
Yet thoſe rich Ornaments were very far
From gracing that fowl Monſter Civil-War.
How ugly then ſhe is when ridden blind,
With Pope before, but Presbyter behind?
Such a poor Nation's caſe is very evil:
Thoſe two wou'd ride a Kingdom to the Devil.
Learn then, by what you have beheld to day,
To keep your wit, and money whileſt you may;
Better at Dice to throw away your Wealth,
Your time at curſed Plays, with Punks your health,
Than by damn'd ſenſeleſs bloudy ſtrifes, about
No one knows what, be trod on by the Rout,
Have your Wealth plunder'd, and your brains beat out,
And dye like Jeſuites to be thought devout.
